content:
Posted: May 25, 2014
												Great game, but incredibly difficult and reminiscent of older games like Ghost 'n Goblins. If you love those old games, you'll love this. This is a game that is almost entirely skill-based. If you want a game that will hold your hand you aren't going to get it here. Every enemy you encounter has a specific way of being defeated that will often require you to have a solid grasp of the fighting and platforming mechanics.There's a limited save system that allows you to resume roughtly where you left off, but you'll need to collect lives in-game--and likely play the game in one-sitting--to beat the optional later levels and get the best ending. That might seem a bit too harsh, but once you get the core gameplay down you'll be able to get to the final boss in about an hour. In short: Difficult, but extremely fun, and with good core gameplay that's difficult without feeling cheap.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												Did you enjoy games like Ghosts 'n Goblins, Super Ghouls 'n Ghosts, or the NES/SNES Castlevania games?  Then buy this. Don't know what they were about? Read on.ChallengeIf you're looking for a game that will hold your hand or provide a lot of guidance, then don't buy this game. Save for showing you the controls at the start and showing a few hints, you have to figure out everything for yourself. The checkpoints are spaced out quite a bit, especially compared to most modern games. Don't expect checkpoints right before the bosses.On the other hand, the levels are short, so once you get the hang of them, getting back to the boss won't take much of your time. Breezing through a level that made you grunt and curse like a viking initially is a clear indication of real progress, not just haphazardly making it to the next checkpoint.You're expected to find safe routes through the environment, and solid tactics for defeating your enemies.Enemy varietyAt the start of each world you'll encounter a new set of enemies, and you'll often see new ones in the second part of the world as well. While some enemies are very similar in appearance (not just palette swaps, though), their moves and properties will differ. The bosses vary greatly in appearance and attack patterns.LevelsThe levels must be attempted in a linear order, though you can choose a harder version of the next world after defeating a boss, provided you're able to loot enough chests without getting hit. You can sometimes choose more difficult paths within levels, which often lead to chests or secrets.There aren't any blind leaps of faith, provided you use the "look ahead" button, though it comes close at times. You can spot hazards by carefully observing the level.The levels have distinc looks and the hazards change as well.ConclusionIf you think a 2D action platformer which will punish you for your mistakes sounds like fun, then buy this game.Edit: Formatting

content:
Posted: December 11, 2013
												This game is HEAVILY inspired to the old coin-op arcade Rastan and you can sense that from the very beginning, looking at the first monsters you encounter and the level layout.Is this a bad thing? HELL NO! This game is truly amazing, takes many good things of old classic arcade games and adapt them to new styles of gameplay.The mechanics of the game are really similar to Ghost'n'Goblins. While you progress you find chests with items inside, if you get hit you'll loose 1 or 2 items. You can get the items only in a specific order: -Shield  (you start with it but you can lose it, it can parry a few hits) ;-HammerShield  (can parry every hit, unlocks the power to charge super spears);-Helmet  (i havent found any specific ability for this, it just grand another layer of defence);-Flame Sword  (deals increased damage).Overall the difficulty could feel a bit frustrating at the beginning, especially if you're used to save your game every few steps.It's gonna be brutal, you'll die a lot, but each time you'll learn a bit more about the level and slowly you'll progress and be able to finish a level without dying.It is really hard, like the old Rastan and Ghost'n'Goblins were, it took me roughly 1 hour to complete the first world, which is divided in 2 levels + boss.Overall i love it, it brings me back to when i was a kid and couldn't wait to go to the Arcade and spend tons of coins to play these beautiful games. This game is just all that...a sweet jump to 20 years ago...with style!

Posted: January 8, 2014
												Let me start off by saying this game is not for the faint hearted! You will die and you will die a lot!!! Unlike Tiny Barbarian this game will test your skills at every corner, it has a steep learning curve that will punish you at every turn.  How you proceed in Volgarr is to die and learn from your mistakes.  Your health is made up by items that you collect along the way, for example your shield and helemt each add an additional Health Point to your armour, each time you get Hit you lose an item until you finally die. Controls are a bit limited and there are no checkpoints along the way.Being such a hard game makes every level you complete feel like such a mammoth victory, having mastered all the enemys, traps and string them together to safley get you through a level actually gives you a sense of accomplishment.  It has the feel of a Money hungry arcade game forcing you to enter more coins and learn the game so that you can progress.  But in saying that the difficulty is just about right to keep you keen enough to complete each level and battle on.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Genre: Action, Adventure, Indie, PlatformerDeveloper: Crazy Viking StudiosPublisher: Adult Swim GamesRelease Date: September 13, 2013The Gods struck lightning upon the land and from the bolts came Volgarr The Viking. This one from Crazy Viking Studios reminds me of the NES version of Dragons Lair, not so much the gameplay but the almost impossibility of completing the first level. Very unforgiving Volgarr The Viking has one difficulty setting, and thats Ralph Wiggum HARD. This is one of those games where what you see is what you get, and reminds me a lot of a SEGA arcade machine that would cost you 25 cents every run. So trust me, if that were the case with this game, you would lose your entire paycheck trying to beat the first level. BUT, that isn’t exactly a bad thing, and I’ll explain why.When I initially started this game, the powerful music combined with the 16 bit SEGA graphics kind of takes you back a bit. I like games with unique introductions like this one, where the start screen is the beginning of the game as well. Volgarr the Viking takes elements from games like Castlevania and Contra, and brings them into the new age while making sure not to jeopardize the retro feel. Not only is this game more brutally violent than a relationship with Chris Brown, but brutally hard. My first time playing after 30 minutes and multiple deaths I still hadn’t made it to the first checkpoint. One of my main concerns reading the early reviews of this game revolved around what many called “clunky, unresponsive controls.” Thankfully after buying Volgarr I found this not to be the case. The dynamics and mechanics are perfectly balanced for this game, and are what I would like to describe as “solid.” Meaning each move must follow through before making the next, so if in the time you are swinging the sword you are hit, you won’t be able to react fast enough and will suffer the consequences.The Game itself doesn’t have much of a story line. When you first start, the Gods declare “Rise Warrior!” as a bolt of lightning strikes the ground Volgarr appears. From there on you start the game immediately and begin the adventure. Starting off you are given a shield, which will act as your main form of defense against the lizardish bird monsters that you are put up against. When you aren’t attacking you are able to block the simple attack so each of the monsters, but the moment you attack you are leaving yourself vulnerable. The shield acts as a hit point. If you get hit, you lose the shield and you are now exposed to everything making your next hit fatal. You can pick up different forms of armor throughout the game by finding and breaking open chests. After getting the shield and helmet you can upgrade your weapon to a flaming sword which is considerably more powerful than the one you begin with. Each different item you are wearing acts as single hit point, each time you are hit you lose an item.As for replay factor, that seems to be all that you will be doing when it comes to Volgarr The Viking, or at least that was my experience. I can say that I have played the game for a good 5 hours in preparation for this review, and within that time I’ve learned to love and hate the game all at the same time. It certainly is hard, and seems impossible, but I guess thats what gives it mystery. The way I look at it, Volgarr The Viking is yet another classic from Adult Swim Studios, and no matter what you love or hate about it, thats what makes it so awesome.Volgarr The Viking stays true to the 16 bit retro feel all the way through. Everything from the controls, graphics, music and mood all remind me of after school gaming sessions with friends, trying to prove who could get further and beat the level. Taking everything into account Volgarr The Viking is a good game, fun to play, and bleeds nostalgia. If you think you have what it takes, go for it, you won’t be disappointed.Graphics: 7/10Playability: 6/10Story: 1/10Challenge: 10/10Replay Value: 6/10

Posted: December 18, 2013
												Short answer:  Yes, buy this game now!Volgarr is one of those games that reminds me why I love video games.  The controls are smooth, and it's easy to shift from attacks to evasive dodges and jumps and back again in fluid motion.  The gameplay is awesome, with a mix of platforming and slashemup action.  The difficulty is about right; not so easy I pass everything on my first try, but not so hard that I can't advance after several attempts (it took me 7 hours to get to the ending, and then another 10 for the best ending, played in 1-2 hour chunks).  And with plenty of secrets and bonus levels to unlock, there's a lot more here than appears at first.  Excellent game!

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 7, 2015
												When a game like Dark Souls is praised as being one of the most difficult games ever made, people of a certain age will remember games such as Contra, Battletoads and Ghosts N' Goblins and then wonder what all the fuss is about.  Volgarr isn't as difficult as these, but it certainly owes its existence to Ghosts N' Goblins and fans of that title and fans of punishing old school games should love homage to the "Golden Age" of arcade gaming.  Volgarr features hand-made pixel animation, epic soundtrack, simple controls and of course...challenging level design.  It isn't a looker, but it doesn't need to be.  Each level never changes, so when you die you will know what is coming and must try and improve for your next attempt.  This meticulous design offers a highly rewarding feeling of accomplishment when you finally overcome a level that has been making you tear your hair out for the last 40 attempts.  This is what the game is all about.  If you hate dying, hate a challenge, need a story and dislike repetition then you must steer clear of this title.  Otherwise, you will be able to flex your gaming muscles and really challenge yourself.  There isn't a lot else to say.  It is a well designed homage to an older generation of games and will instantly appeal to fans of the NES platformer era.  The game is never unfair, so if you are apprehensive about picking this up, at least look for it on sale and give it a chance.

Although this game is not for the faint of heart I feel this simplistic hardcore classic will be loved by many.

Posted: March 29, 2014
												Volgarr is a throwback to certain challenging 16-bit platformers, namely Super Ghouls 'N Ghosts and Rastan. The graphics are a little odd- they look kind of like a SNES game with the "filtering" turned on to make the pixels look smoothed, but I actually do like them. More importantly, the mechanics are top notch. With these kind of games, controls and mechanics absolutely make or break the game. Volgarr has Rastan style swordplay (attack while moving, block with shield, etc) and Ghouls 'N Ghosts style platforming (a nice, crisp-feeling double jump) and powerups (chests upgrade your shield/armor/weapon depending on what you've got currently, allowing you to use new moves and take more hits). Volgarr has a sword and a spear, and that's it. The game really makes it work, giving you a range of options. You can fight while moving, play defensive and trade blows with your shield, dodge roll, jump attack, downstab, throw spears, charge spear attack, throw spears in midair, throw spears into walls to make new platforms, and so on. All of this is highly intuitive and you'll find yourself doing some really cool maneuvers very naturally. I kind of amazed myself just now when I jumped into an area, threw a spear in midair to kill a wasp, downstabbed to kill a lizardman, dodge rolled past an arrow trap, and then jumped onto a spear I threw earlier to climb out of the pit before another arrow could fire. It's important to know that Volgarr is very oldschool. That means no saving. Every time you launch the game, there isn't even a start menu, Volgarr is borne out of blood and bone and you start killing lizardmen immediately. You begin from level 1 every time you launch the game. You do have infinite lives, but checkpoints aren't highly frequent, and you'll need to beat the game in one sitting. I believe that beating a level without dying takes you down an alternate path for the next level, and beating the entire game without dying gives you a secret ending. My only complaint is that I wish that the game had better music. It deserves more metal music!

Posted: December 23, 2013
												I'll probably never beat Volgar, but that's part of its appeal. It has great controls, everything feels tight and precise. The enemy types are clearly identified, green Nose-Beaks takes one hit, blue two, red three, and so on. The spear's simple/easy to use, and is necessary for traversal. The games core is its difficulty. It is very hard to get from checkpoint to checkpoint, but when you do progress the sense of achievement is genuine. It never feels like the obstacles are impossible or cheap. Once you know where the deathtraps are it's up to your skill to get past them. The game is hard but not unfair and I keep coming back for more. I definitely recommend.

Posted: May 24, 2014
												If you like Super Ghouls n Ghosts, you probably already like this game.First off, the saving in this game is done once you beat the boss at the end of each world. When you first start a stage, move immediately to the left to skip that world.The platforming mechanics are solid, which is what you want in a platformer. You can –with timed double jumps– be precise with your movement once you learn how. The enemies are ok, including bosses none of them have random elements from what I can tell, so you can plan everything before you jump into a fight once you've learned the patterns. This is a good thing for speed running, but it makes the game feel sanitary sometimes. The game usually shows you a new enemy or trap relatively safely before including it in the rest of the level too, which is nice. The graphics are pretty much what you'd see on a SNES or Sega Genesis/Mega Drive, which better suits this style of game in my opinion.Overall I'd give it an 8/10, not the best platformer ever, but it's the best one I've played in a long time. There is also a hard version for all (but the first?) worlds, which is explained to you in the credits if you hadn't figured it out already. If you want checkpoints every 2 minutes, this isn't the game for you.

Posted: November 6, 2015
												I get this game is made for the prupose of being a challenging but rewarding game. And if you love that stuff you may like this game. It has a lot going for it but has two big problems:- Jump control is too uncompromising - The amount of tedious work you have to do over again when you die - i.e. lack of checkpoints.I've played games with infrequent checkpoints and its normally more enjoyable because you don't feel like you are trudging through the same stuff you have already perfected just to get to the harder stuff. There is some sense of variety that keeps it interesting every time you die (Dark Souls or Hitman games if you are trying to stay stealthy).The jumping to me seems like it is designed to screw you over more often than help you. I'd prefer good control of my character with harder obstacles rather than feel like I can't make use of this guy because the controls are so rigid.Despite all that though it's honestly worth a couple bucks to try because if the jumping doesn't bother you and you are a masochist, you'll probably find a lot of value in the game.

Posted: February 8, 2015
												Old school arcade style hardcore game with good and fair game design. This game gets a lot of hate because it doesn't follow modern game design. But what most people don't realize is that most of their complains are part of the design. Which means it won't appeal to a lot of people.Volgarr has some game design decisions that I feel is unappreciated. This video (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ThvRVYuDo34) explains a good example of their design, specifically, how to introduce enemies which the player sees for the first time.Here are some common complaints about the game:*Checkpoints*: Yes, the checkpoints are real far apart. But the designers are trying to push for an arcade experience where you get better the more you play the game. If you have less frequent checkpoints, the levels will more memorable since you'll be playing it more. Also, the design of the power-up system means that the checkpoint cannot be near the boss. Here is the dev's statement on check points: http://steamcommunity.com/app/247240/discussions/0/846965056727179788 . *Jump arc*: People say the jumping is stiff. But the entire game is built around that. Think of the original Castlevania games. The character has an uncontrollable jump arc but you can still reach the platforms. The same can be said about Volgarr. If you see a pit, you can simply jump over it. No need to double jump.*It feels that you have to play perfectly*: Not true at all. When I started playing, I felt this way but as I progress, I noticed small tricks that I can use. For example, the shield can be used to block a lot of attacks including those intimidating ones used by tougher enemies]. Once I figured that out, I was able to progress through the stages way faster by just using that item since most enemies have a delay after attacking. The game didn't teach me that but it was something that I noticed later. And when I decided to experiment, I felt the game rewarded me for my lateral thinking.This game rewards patience and methodological play. Which is why most gamers don't this game a second chance. It takes many playthroughs to see the brilliance of the game. The people who stick with it to the end will have the most rewarding feeling of accomplishment. They will feel that they've earned it.Sadly, this game isn't for everyone. If you're the kind of person who gets frustrated at repeating a level over and over again until completion, this isn't for you. The game's core design is that this is an arcade game meant to be played over and over again so you'll gain the skill needed to complete the game. Tl;dr: give the game a chance. You'll get frustrated, but that's part of the design. Because nothing beats the feeling of you overcoming the game's obstacle is throwing at you.

Posted: March 29, 2014
												Volgarr is a throwback to certain challenging 16-bit platformers, namely Super Ghouls 'N Ghosts and Rastan. The graphics are a little odd- they look kind of like a SNES game with the "filtering" turned on to make the pixels look smoothed, but I actually do like them. More importantly, the mechanics are top notch. With these kind of games, controls and mechanics absolutely make or break the game. Volgarr has Rastan style swordplay (attack while moving, block with shield, etc) and Ghouls 'N Ghosts style platforming (a nice, crisp-feeling double jump) and powerups (chests upgrade your shield/armor/weapon depending on what you've got currently, allowing you to use new moves and take more hits). Volgarr has a sword and a spear, and that's it. The game really makes it work, giving you a range of options. You can fight while moving, play defensive and trade blows with your shield, dodge roll, jump attack, downstab, throw spears, charge spear attack, throw spears in midair, throw spears into walls to make new platforms, and so on. All of this is highly intuitive and you'll find yourself doing some really cool maneuvers very naturally. I kind of amazed myself just now when I jumped into an area, threw a spear in midair to kill a wasp, downstabbed to kill a lizardman, dodge rolled past an arrow trap, and then jumped onto a spear I threw earlier to climb out of the pit before another arrow could fire. It's important to know that Volgarr is very oldschool. That means no saving. Every time you launch the game, there isn't even a start menu, Volgarr is borne out of blood and bone and you start killing lizardmen immediately. You begin from level 1 every time you launch the game. You do have infinite lives, but checkpoints aren't highly frequent, and you'll need to beat the game in one sitting. I believe that beating a level without dying takes you down an alternate path for the next level, and beating the entire game without dying gives you a secret ending. My only complaint is that I wish that the game had better music. It deserves more metal music!

Posted: December 23, 2013
												I'll probably never beat Volgar, but that's part of its appeal. It has great controls, everything feels tight and precise. The enemy types are clearly identified, green Nose-Beaks takes one hit, blue two, red three, and so on. The spear's simple/easy to use, and is necessary for traversal. The games core is its difficulty. It is very hard to get from checkpoint to checkpoint, but when you do progress the sense of achievement is genuine. It never feels like the obstacles are impossible or cheap. Once you know where the deathtraps are it's up to your skill to get past them. The game is hard but not unfair and I keep coming back for more. I definitely recommend.

Posted: March 8, 2016
												A very unforgiving, but also very rewarding old-school platformer.By the old school, I dont mean the wellmade retro graphics, but the gameplay and difficulty level of the game.It doesnt work like the standard SuperMeatBoy-wannabe-games with retro graphics, Volgarr is very different to them.You die, die, die again, and when you die, you better pay attention to why did you die and how you can avoid it next time, to survive and get through this game. You dont need fast reflexes or hyper controlling skills to pass this game. All you really need is patience, ability to pay attention to your surroundings, and being able to learn from your mistakes.After that, the game is almost like a puzzle-platformer. As long as you know how enemies and traps handle and know the limitations of your character, and take a lot of patience, you can get through the game without dying a single time. If you fail at those but try to push through the levels with brute force and trust in your skills, you will never complete even the first level.These days, games designed this way are very very rare, and for one willing to try one, give it a try. The challenges of Volgarr are not for everyone though.

Posted: August 31, 2015
												This game is like a love letter to the hardest arcade games of the past.  It's like they combined the best elements of Ghouls & Ghosts with Rastan & made a super tough arcade action platform experience.Just know that this game is hard.  Really really hard.  After 5 hours I haven't beaten the 2nd level HARD.~PROS-Solid Action/Platform Mechanics-Classic Arcade Style Elements-Easy to Learn/Hard to Master-Level Select Feature-Two Different Adventures~CONS-VERY HIGH DifficultyJust know before you play this game that you will die a lot & you will need to play it a lot in order to get good enough to beat even the first level, then even more for the following levels.  If you've got the time to put in & aquire the neccessary skill to beat the game then you should pick it up.  Even if you don't, you'll still get a kick out of it if you enjoy classic arcade style games.The game has a lot going for it & a lot of hidden goodies like the level select.  After you beat a level, you can skip it simply by moving left at the beginning of the stage.  Of course, if you want to do the Valkyrie levels you will need to play through the entire game on one life & earn Valkyrie Souls by opening all the chests.  If you're able to get through a level without getting hit & opening all the chests you gain credits that enable you to choose the Valkyrie levels after you beat a stage.  Just know that the Valkyrie stages are much harder than the Viking ones & the Viking ones are already pretty darn hard.When you go through the game you should take in your surroundings & treat everything like a puzzle because it's pretty much set up to be done a certain way.  If you manage to figure it out you can progress through it with near perfection & not getting hit a single time.Overall, if you like classic arcade style action platform games then you should get this one.  It's worth every penny & if you can get it on a sale then that's even better.  All the frustration is worth it if you can somehow play through this game to the end.  Heck, I still haven't been able to do it but I'm gonna keep trying.

												The obvious: Volgarr is challenging.The less obvious: it is so challenging that it will undoubtedly frustrate you repeatedly (no matter how good you think you are).Volgarr is a difficult game that feels very rewarding when you achieve progress. Defeating the first sector feels incredible, finishing off the first boss feels great, and even when the next levels seem daunting, slow but sure progress gets you to the end. Most people will give it up before the end, but even if you don't finish the game it is worth a shot.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 11, 2014
												Obligatory header to the review: I focus on four primary areas whenever I review a game: gameplay, story, graphics, and sound/audio/general things that go into your earholes. Gameplay and Story get a rating scale from 1 to 10, and the AV stuff gets a rating from 1 to 5. My philosophy on this is that there are some instances in which a game may not necessarily have that much in the way of gameplay (take Amnesia for example), but the story/atmosphere/whatever it may be is reason enough to pick it up. Also, take the cumulative score with a grain of salt; it's just a numerical feeling about the game as a whole. That's part of why I do these subscores. Also, keep in mind that I'm not going off of school grade based rankings. A 5/10 denotes what I feel to be an average game. Likewise, 7/10 is a game that I think is pretty cool, and something that gets a 2/10 is near-abomination level. Pinning scores to an even further obfuscated rating scale is kinda senseless, but for the sake of my backloggery, I'll repeat again that 1.0-2.7 is a one-star game, 3.0-4.7 is a two-star game, 5.0-6.7, 7.0-8.7, and 9.0-10 are three, four, and five stars, respectively.Gameplay: Man, Adult Swim Games sure have been publishing some pretty great titles. I think this one is top of the pile, though. The fact that this game doesn't have a Wikipedia page as of the time of writing is a great injustice to just how good this game is. In fact, a friend of mine named this game his Game of the Year for 2013. After playing through the game myself, I can certainly see why he'd say this. One phrase he used to describe this game is "a 2D Dark Souls." While the best phrase to describe this game is a "newer Ghouls 'n' Ghosts game;" in fact the studio's vision for this game, that can conjure up negative ideas about the game's design and how it handles difficulty. For now, just think of it as a 2D Dark Souls.After some retrospection, I found that my first playthrough of this game was auspiciously similar to my first playthrough of Dark Souls. In both games, I was never too sure of the control scheme at first, but once I got used to it (and in this case, stopped using the analog stick in favor of the D-Pad (no seriously, the D-Pad on any controller beats the analog stick for this game)), I found that the control scheme worked perfectly for the game. Combat, much like Dark Souls, is very accurate and weighty. Likewise, this game has some excellent hitboxes; in fact, sometimes a bit too excellent. That's not a criticism, though; just know that you can get beaned in the head with an arrow even if your shield is extended, since your shield doesn't cover your head.Another comparison to Dark Souls is the fact that this game does the most vital thing in a difficult video game (in my opinion), and that's signaling. You can do whatever you want to enhance the challenge of a level, as long as there's proper signaling. Again, the comparison between this and Dark Souls arises; both games were excellent at signaling, meaning that there were never any cheap deaths. Stages are surmountable without any memorization necessary, although if you're kinda dumb like me when it comes to video games, some memorization may be necessary. Plus, this game does that magical thing where you just get better at stages. That's a true sign of a well designed challenge level; where you can come back later on and find it easier without needing memorization. Overall, this game is a masterpiece in challenge level and level design.In fact, my only real gripe is how this game handles bosses. Each stage is broken up into two halves - much like Ghouls 'n' Ghosts - with a boss at the end of the second half. This is a thing that I've thought about for a while now, and I think it may just be an unfortunate necessity due to how the game handles health (you get bits of armor and weapon upgrades from chests throughout the level and lose them if you're hit; again, pretty much exactly like Ghouls 'n' Ghosts). Either that, or it may be a bit more rigid conformity to the Ghouls 'n' Ghosts design ethos. The bosses themselves are fairly easy and incredibly patternated, so once you get the pattern down, you should have no problems with the bosses. This may just be me injecting my personal design sensibilties, but I feel like the bosses could've been a lot better if there was a checkpoint beforehand (along with making the bosses harder overall, of course).Again, though; this isn't too big of an issue, but it is one that I thought could've been handled in a bit different (and in my opinion better, but you've figured that out already) manner. Nevertheless, I can definitely see why this was my friend's Game of the Year for 2013. While I can't necessarily make a statement about 2013 with regards to games, since I just started PC gaming in October 2013, if it had came out this year, it would most certainly be Game of the Year for 2014 for me. Yes, that means beating out Dark Souls II. 10/10.Story: Literally the only story you get is a credits scroll at the end. Not even gonna rate.Graphics: Man, there's some pretty great looking art in this game. The graphics feel like an "HD Genesis/Mega Drive game," which once again fits perfectly with the Ghouls 'n' Ghosts inspiration. All of the enemy designs are great, there's detail practically oozing out of every pixel laid down, and it still looks great at 1080p. My only gripe with enemy designs are the bosses of level 2 and level 5. They're literally reskins of enemies in the area. All the other bosses are unique designs, but boss 2 and 5 are somewhat disappointing. That's not too big of a deal, though; the core enemy design is great anyways. Of course the game runs well, so there's no worry about not being able to run it. Even though it windows at a relatively low resolution, it fullscreens to match your resolution of choice without a hassle. 5/5.Sound: I've found that I like a lot of brass and percussion in my orchestration. This game... delivers a LOT of brass and percussion. This makes sense, of course; we're a viking, after all. We don't want a panflute chronicling our journey; no, we want big, bombastic horns, tubas, timpanis... the whole nine yards. Suffice to say, the music in this game is good. Really good. So good that I grabbed the OST literal minutes after I completed the game. There's no voiceacting in this game, so I don't really need to worry about that. I think it's pretty obvious that a 5/5 is in order for this game's sound department.Overall scores are 10/0/5/5; cumulative score of 10/10. Yeah, this is Game of the Year material. You should probably buy this game before a viking busts down your door and impales you with a flaming spear of awesomeness.

												This is a fantastic action-platformer that fans of old SNES-era platformers will appreciate. The level design and pacing of the game are great, the secrets are well hidden, and every level has a simple, challenging, and fun boss battle at the end. The pixel art on display here is vibrant and colorful, and is perfectly matched with some great music that fits the mood of the game. If you're like me and you've been longing for a great game that will remind you of the good ol' SNES days but not make you relive them, then you should pick this game up.

content:
Posted: April 6
												Amazing game.  There isn't really much I can say about the gameplay mechanics, graphics, and sound design that hasn't already been said over and over, so I won't touch on those things.  I played this one through on both Steam, and on the Dreamcast.  The game is smoother on PC, but the DC port is totally playable.  If you do decide to play it on the Dreamcast, please buy it for one of the other platforms.  It's a really amazing game and the devs and publisher deserve to get paid for it.A common complaint I see is with this game's difficulty.  Personally, I think the difficulty of the gameplay is fair, but I wish there were a few more checkpoints.  Each stage is divided into two section, and each section has a checkpoint at the beginning.  You die, you restart at the beginning of the section.  And to make it worse, the boss for each stage is at the end of the second section.  If you die at the boss, you restart the whole section.   Maybe a checkpoint before a boss would be enough?  That would create a new issue though, since the player then wouldn't be able to fully upgrade their gear through the level after dying to a boss.  It'd have to be an optional checkpoint.  Whatever the case, I'm sure the devs are capable enough to figure out how to make that work.That is literally my only gripe with the Volgarr the Viking.  I've played it probably 12 hours on the Dreamcast on top of the time I have invested in the game on Steam.  I think it's a solid and fun game, and I love a challenge.  I'm currently working on completing the Valkyrie path, which is essentially a different version of each level with limited lives.  It's basically the hard mode for an already really hard game.  After that, I intend to speedrun it.  I totally got my $10 worth.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
												If Ghouls and Ghosts and Actraiser had a baby, and they had a twisted uncle called Donkey Kong Country, then that's where Volgarr came from. A new game done in the style of old, it really is quite a gem. Simplistic as can be in terms of gameplay, though that is not to say that learning how to control Volgarr is not an obstacle with a nice skill ceiling. Some may consider his controls rather rigid, but if you learn how to use him, he's fluid and most importantly, much like Ghouls and Ghosts, very fair. Remember guys, sometimes you have to jump back a bit before you jump forward to get to where you want to go -- little ghouls and ghosts tip for those not used to this jumping system.From a level design perspective, I personally quite enjoy both paths of the game. However, I think overall the Valkyrie path has superior level design. The crystal path suffers a bit from too many enemies and not enough platforming, but, that may be your thing. Enemies are in and of themselves obstacles, but the game is at it's best when you have to manage both at the same time. So learn to Volgarr well and experience the bliss of the Valkyrie path.The soundtrack is pretty good, but not good enough to warrant listening to it beyond your 50th hour of playing -- though I think most won't play it that much, so you're fine!From a replayability perspective, the game doesn't offer much variety once you complete both paths. There are no alternative ways to play, so, once you've beat it, you can either stop there, or grit your teeth and become the best Volgarr player you can be. As a speedgame, Volgarr is simple, but very skillful and both a joy to play and to watch. It may not look particularly "fast", but, trust me, there's always time to save. So if speedrunning is your thing, by all means pick it up and grace the leaderboard -- please, I seriously wish more people ran this game.RISE WARRIOR!-- From a guy who has too many hours in this game, with only many more to come. (And, I should note, I have the GoG version of this game as well, so... there's more time devoted to this than just what steam wants to tell you.)

content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												Volgarr the Viking has its fun aspects but is at best a mediocre game that should still be classified as beta. While it tries to have a retro feel, it really doesn't. As one who played the old school games since Digger was the♥♥♥♥♥♥ I would say that I can recognise a old school feel of platform gaming. And let me just say, I LOVE platform games. But this doesn't feel at all like one of the classics. In general it feels like a lazy unthought through failed attempt.There are several major problems with the game. The first being the clumsy movements. Especially the jump movements are very badly made. It's quite easy to get into a position where you will need to jump to move on, but jumping in any direction will have a very high dead likeliness. There is simply a lack of fine manoeuvring witch make "precision" (and really, it didn't really have to be that precise) impossible. This has lead to many stupid deaths which didn't really reflect how hard the game is as much as it reflects a badly made game.But perhaps the most annoying thing is how often you have to start from the beginning. The game has very accurately been described as a "trial and error" game and it is highly unlikely that you will finish the game in the first few attempts. This would be okay if it didn't mean that you had to restart the game from the very beginning almost every time. Meaning that you waste enormous amounts of time replaying parts that are no longer fun and that you have cleared to perfection dozen of times, just to get to the part you haven't played before. This is even to the point that when you close the game, you have to restart from the beginning again. In the old school platform games there was actually save options, something that isn't here. And in the games where there weren't save options, there was often the option of putting in a code that would bring you to a certain point in the game (a code you got for completing a level).A game is supposed to be fun and I do think that parts of this game is fun. BUT it is in no way fun having to replay the same part for the million time! That is just stupid, a waste of time and a waste of money. So please, if you want a nice old school platform game, what about actually playing one of the old school games? Like Duke Nukem 1 and 2, Mario, Jazz Jackrabbit, Sonic, Realm of Terror, Pandemonium, Lost Vikings 1 and 2, Hocus Pocus or any of the other old classics. And have you already played al of these? Then there are many more, please comment if you want more suggestions :)But please, don't reward laziness, false marketing and bad gameplay with you money. That will just push them to make more of this crap instead of actually getting their act together and making that good game they probably could if they worker a bit more serious.PS: By the way, there was always a story in the old games. This is also lacking here and another sign of the laziness behind the game.PPS: The setting is stupid. Seriously? Vikings in the steaming jungle filled with lizardmen? You do know that Vikings lived in northern Europe, right? Where it's cold or tempered, not steaming jungle? Ice warriors, something along the coast or anything like that, see that would be using the Viking name properly, not insulting it to sell a bad game.PPS: As one who actually grew up with the old school games, I have to say that none of them ever had this bad graphics... Almost every single game here on steam that tries to recreate the looks of the old 80s and 90s games, actually ends up making their games look a lot worse and more clumsy.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												I enjoy challenging games, especially when they look as pretty as Volgarr. The only problem I have with challenging games in this instance is the very nature of the challenge: trial and error. This is by no means old school platforming, merely a modern take on platforming where fun is replaced with frustration and called a challenge. For an old school game, I have played it about as much as I need to in order to assess what I love and and hate about it.I love the graphics and the sound, which are top notch, old school throwbacks. The graphics are detailed and thoroughly eye-opening, especially when you're swinging around the fire sword. The sounds that compliment it are simple, catchy tunes with very little in the way of complexity, again allowing you into the world of Volgarr easily and without much trying. What I hate about this game is the absurd view the developers have of what makes a game challenging. Forcing a player back to the beginning of the level, then making them get back to where they died, travel an extra few feet and die to something else they couldn't possibly anticipate, is frankly insulting. I lost my cool with the first level because the enemies that spawned did so differently from death to death, making my learning of the level impossible. When I finally did get through a difficult wave of enemies and pratfalls, I was faced with an arrow trap that just shot me in the face without me even having time to move out of the way. I dislike games that do away with fun and Volgarr certainly did for me.For those of you who have the tolerance to sit through death after death, this is a game for you (especially for dark souls players), but if you enjoy a really good platformer, buy some of the mega drive classics and fusion games like risk of rain to get the best out of your money. Volgarr would have been superb if it was anything like the classics it was trying so hard to emulate. Ghouls and ghosts for the new generation? Absolutely no doubt...

number of helpful: 8 of 15 people (53%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												After only 3 hours of gameplay (and counting- I'm not throwing in the towel just yet), I've beaten Level 1 a few times, and I've quit two different ways:  clicking the X, and selecting the Quit Game option. Neither one saved my progress, so next time I'd go to play, I'd have to start at Level 1. What am I doing wrong here? I understand Volgarr is supposed to be difficult (which it is), but shouldn't I be able to see just HOW difficult it is by being able to get past the first 2 levels? I mean, how about some mid-level checkpoints? And how about a world map where I can pick and choose levels that I've already beaten (should that ever happen), and not some bland, "follow the yellow brick road" system.And what all cool upgrades for Volgarr lie beyond Level 2? I looked it up. Additional weapons? Nope. More armor? Nope. Wielding the Fire Sword for more than 5 seconds before getting hit and losing it? Hopefully. Furthermore, why does getting hit while wielding said Fire Sword also cause me to also lose my helmet? That's TWO pieces of equipment lost from ONE hit! The upgrade/armor/health system reflects that of Super Mario Bros., but Volgarr's first two levels aren't nearly supplied with as many treasure chests (where upgrades are found) as Mario's first two levels were with question mark blocks, and some of Mario's blocks had stars.Also, when you slaughter enemies they will sometimes drop treasure, which is used for leaderboards. That's cool, but I find it hard to focus on killing every single Lizardman, hoping they drop treasure, just to top the leaderboards when I'm trying to survive until the next treasure chest. Perhaps with all this treasure to collect, a Sonic-type health system would've made sense.However, the controls are simple, the graphics are nice and accurately reflect the retro aethestic of its SNES counterparts, and the triumphant battle themes remind me of the good old days of splurging quarters on Gauntlet Legends.I REALLY wanted to like this game, and [adult swim] is an entertainment brand I trust. The trailers make Volgarr look like a fun challenge, not a frustrating chore. Until some issues are addressed, I cannot fully recommend this game.TL;DR:  Gee, I can't wait to get to Level 3.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												The gameplay and mechanics seem fine, but the problem comes from the level design. The game becomes difficult not due to actual challenge, but due to level flow. Enemies are as close to a "bullet hell" game as a "mostly" ground-pounder game can be, but when you have to stop the flow of action to line up a jump properly due to poor level design it's very immersion breaking. Overlooking that, it strives for "Nintendo Hard" but is more a systematic issue with the stilted nature of the control scheme that provides the real challenge. Whereas the enemies themselves are reasonably predictable, and it's usually the inability to respond that kills you and not the challenge presented by the enemies. With an improvement in the controls and a smoother level design, it could be great, but having recently played many other platfomers, the sluggish combat animations and stuttering jumping sequences really stick out in an otherwise "nostalgic" platformer.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
												This game defines artificial difficulty.It's undoubtedly gorgeous and makes the player feel bad@$$ when they pull off the right moves, but it's absolutely infuriating at the same time. You keep dying at the same places making the same mistakes, which makes you want to snap your monitor in half. You'd have to play this game to feel it, really; you can find upgrades to make Volgarr take more hits before he dies, but it ends at 3 or 4, and you're just as fragile as your enemies.Yes, I know it's supposed to be difficult, but it fails at that. It's simply cheap. You have to know exactly where to stand in particular situations, where to throw your spears to make platforms for Volgarr, from where you need to start a jump so as not to overshoot it... The challenge is far ahead of fun in this case, I'd say.Yes, I did play my share of properly tough games, too.The only game more unfair than this I can think of is Magicka.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												This is indeed a beautiful game. Graphics are great, animations too. The music and ambience are both good too.Then, why I do not recommend this game?Because of it's gameplay. And not because it's difficult, that's not the point. The problem here is the "fake" difficulty. The ONLY reason to play this game for more than 30 mins it's not the story (there is none), it's not the graphics or the music: it's the gameplay. But it lacks any depth, it's about memorizing patterns, dying and repeating over and over until you get things right. It's not difficult because the game has good AI, or because enemies are unpredictable. It's difficult because we're not used to this kind of games, and after dying 20 times and reaching the second checkpoint full geared you realize that it's not challenging, it's boring, plain and simple.If you like to memorize patterns and play for hours without really any kind of motivation except to complete a game so you can tell your friends "hey, u know what? I finished volgarr the viking, i'm such a pro player", then this game is for you.If you're looking for a game with a story, with good IA, or with a real challenge that goes beyond dying and repeating the same thing over and over, then this is not for you.

												This is one fun, fas-paced Ghosts`n`Goblins type of hack`n`slasher, with a gameplay that resembles Super Mario World, in a weird way. number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 17, 2013
												If you are on your way to Valhalla... be sure you have earned your place there.Volgarr the Viking is a game that seems to have done everything wrong. The checkpoint system - or its near absence - makes you go back to the beggining of the stage each time you die. The challenge lies mostly in fixed patterns, so running the same section over and over to master it is necessary. Air control seems lacking, making even the easiest jumps a potential death trap.  Moreover, the game is short - only 7 levels, if you count in the one awarded to a player beating the hardmode. So many flaws in one game. You know what? It creates a perfect sidescrolling action game.Volgarr gives you a challenge to beat the game, and does not care if it's too hard for you. Every time you die near the end of a section knowing that you have to spend next 10 minutes redoing the stage, the game gives you a choice of just quitting it. And you don't, because it has just made it personal. Every time you die to a boss you feel like you should give up - but Volgarr motivates you to just try harder and do better next time. And when you finally beat the stage - I've never played a game that gave me so much satisfaction after that. The game is never unfair. You have a level to complete, that's all. All you can do is to master the controls of the viking and learn the weaknesses of you enemies.The graphics are great. Volgarr looks like a real badass viking, equipping more and more awesome armor and weapons at every step. The effects of his flame sword attacks are just glorious. The audio is stunning, providing you with top-class effects during combat and amazing sounds congratulating you on completing the challenges. Also, this is the only title with credit screen so good that I don't even think about skipping it at the end of the game. I won't spoil the fun, experience it for yourself.If you seek for a nice, fair challenge, get Volgarr. If you are an old-time gamer of NES era and want to relive some of the spirit of Castlevania and Ninja Gaiten, get Volgarr. If you are tired of games that hold your hand at every second, get Volgarr. If you want to play a great game, get Volgarr.And good luck.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14, 2015
												Before reading the below review proper. If you would like a short and blunt summary of what this game is see the following video I did in my series for the final boss. This is the essence of the game once you strip away the fake difficulty, purposefully reimplemented arcade bugs and checkpoint starvation.


YouTube™ Video: Volgarr the Viking #4 | OH MAN THIS FINAL BOSS WAS A DOOZY 

			Views: 51		

			This wasn't a challenging game (as demonstrated by that boss fight). It was tedious. Taking the worst growing pain attributes from arcades along with the quarter poaching techniques and bugs isn't...		

If you really want more than that here is the playlist for the series. Now without further ado here is the original review. My final impressions have not changed after completing the game.You know. I had almost forgotten why I never really had any nostalgic feelings towards arcade games that inspired this one. What with their stiff controls, sparse checkpoints/continues for more efficient padding and quarter poaching, edge of screen spawning of enemies and other such fake difficulty. It's always nice to have a game come along and remind me. Funny thing is, the edge of screen spawning was actually technically justified at the time due to memory/sprite constraints and the state keeping issues that entailed. Now? Not so much.If you want a real game that takes the pleasing challenge of arcades but doesn't rely on "but teh retro" as an excuse for its shortcomings check out something like They Bleed Pixels. That said though, be sure you look at the manual for this. They did a really great job on it making it look like how manuals used to look back when they were interesting and filled with lore (Zelda's manual being the most famous for example).Oh and to answer the question a lot of people may have about this. No. There is no pre-boss checkpoints. You die and you have to do the whole level again. This isn't challenging, it's padding. Bad padding at that.Anyway, I noticed that the mouthbreather brigade was telling people that they didn't like it because it was challenging and they couldn't win (as well as calling people "kid" when their argument is called out, proving yet again that they're mostly kids themselves that don't have the slightest clue what these games were about and yet put on a facade of nostalgia), I decided to finish the first world (update: make that the entire game). I'm kind of glad too because it gave me more ammo in the form of this nonsense.I remember those games too. But you're  deluded if you think that you have the same ability to give these ultimatums that lazy companies who didn't want to do battery backups did in the 80s and 90s. Once again, this isn't challenging or a homage. It's a fundamental misunderstanding of the difference between features and technical workarounds.

Challenge was what made those games good, bad check points do not add anything.Fun game but I can't recomend it.

												Hard does not even begin to do this game justice.  Volgarr could give ghosts and goblins a run for its money...yet, for all that, it is still enjoyable.  It's a frustrating, difficult action platformer, with sometimes annoying deaths that could have been avoided with a little foresight, but overall, quite enjoyable. number of helpful: 8 of 16 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
												Volgarr is two different games in one.Played normally, Volgarr feels like a clunky frustration platformer harking back to the old days of Ghouls n Ghosts. Volgarr himself plods along at a decent speed, but is flatly underequipped for most of what the game throws at him. The challenges are simple but Volgarr is simpler. You plod along, hopping about, dying a lot, learning the levels, and generally barely avoiding boredom because nothing in this game is done especially well.Until...You find the second game. As you repeat the levels over and over, you start to get a feel for what needs to be done. You'll brush up against that second game a few times before you finally realize what's going on. The levels are actually meticulously designed. If you move quickly, throw spears at the right times, and generally play the game as if you're speedrunning, the levels will come together. Every single stupid thing in the game becomes easily surmountable when you deal with it the second it comes on the screen. Enemies will line up perfectly to be killed with one spear, platforming will go by as quick as Volgarr's lumbering gait takes him...This is the true Volgarr the Viking. It's not a platformer in the classic since, it's a trial and error speedrunner without the speed. Almost like a rhythm game at times only you can really only find out what the notes are and when by blindly stumbling over them and restarting anew. Since the game's final level can really only be unlocked by beating each level without getting hit and with finding the secret macguffin in each level, this really is what they intended for the game.It's meticulously designed to foster perfect play while doing next to nothing to teach perfect play. Hell, the game barely teaches you the core mechanics except in one of those passive tutorials that people who watched that one MMX1 video are so fond of.The problem is... it still doesn't make the game all that good. Any imperfect run just falls back into that first, really boring game (Only now with the knowledge that you are screwed out of anything satisfying knowing what you missed.), and high-end Volgarr play just does not satisfy enough to be worth the trial and error grinding to perfect each level.

content:
Posted: January 2
												I wish the "recommend this game" wasn't as simple as a yes or no. Because I'm on the maybe fence. I suppose if I keep it simple. Is it a good game? Yeah I enjoy it. It's fun to play.However there is a huge, huge flaw in this game which is probably why I will stop playing it. It's too f@cking hard. Don't get me wrong, I love a challenge. But this game basically starts to suck the fun out of gaming.Diffiulty levels? Nope. Just 1... Okay I can live with that. But the two unforgivable features with this game is how every time you die, you have to go all the way back to the bigging of the level. I have since learned that while it might not appear this way, there are actually checkpoints. You just have to beat the boss for each level to essentially save your spot the next time you play.I don't want this review to seem overly negative because I do like the game. I just think it could have been even better. For the price? yeah give it a go. Just be prepaired.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2015
												Volgarr the Viking is a 2D old school side scroller - you're in for a chalenge and you'll love it. The graphics are old school but nevertheless good for what the game is, gameplay is old school awesome - you atack and you jump and double jump, and less but not least you have a throwing spear atack. You gain equipment as you progress but tread carefuly, if you're hit you will lose one piece of it until you die. If you fall into lava or a bottomless pit your old school insta killed. Music is very good at times and fits well into the world.Achievments and diferent endings provide replayability.You're in for an adventure.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 30, 2015
												Jump controls: garbageEverything else: excellentI have zero tolerance for the jump controls in this game, so I'm sending it to the graveyard, but I could potentially recommend it for its good points to anyone else who can handle the terrible jumping.--If you don't press a direction at the same time you press the jump button, you will only jump vertically instead of in the direction you are trying to go. This is made worse by the fact that, once your feet leave the ground, you have no control over your character in the air and just have to wait for them to fall wherever the trajectory takes them. This double strike gets very annoying, as the game demands quick reflexes and precision in both platforming and combat.Basically they are going for an old school Ghouls n' Ghosts type thing, but even as a person who grew up on those systems, I can't claim to have much nostalgia for the bad aspects of those games. I mean, I enjoyed Ghouls n' Ghosts and still do, but that game doesn't demand precision out of you right away, does not require you to rote memorize the layout of the level, and has waaaaay more checkpoints.I don't want to give it a thumbs down, because I realize the controls are kind of an homage, and everything else about the game is quite good, but damn. I just hate the platforming.

content:
Posted: October 23, 2015
												I was really disappointed by this game. At first, I really liked the graphical pixel design as well as the soundtrack, mainly because it's very minimalistic but does not feel like some 8 Bit peeptone concert. Plus it is a game about a Viking, which I personally really enjoy hence there are not many Viking-themed games out there.BUT! The game is not just horrendously hard, it's unfair. Where games like Dark Souls give you enough time to explore and try some moves etc. here you have almost constantly enemies spawning from everywhere and you cannot see them because you range of view is quite small, therefore you often cannot react fast enough. Addicionally the feeling of the jumping mechanic is really outdated for a 2D sidescroller, meaning once you jumped you cannot change your direction exept you do a double jump. But even jumping onto a little block in your way will be pretty difficult because you jump to far. It's supposed to be like this because it used to be this way in the classical 2D sidescrolling era. But it doesn't make it automaticly a good thing. For me it just feels clunky, difficult to control and overall outdated. The problem with the difficulty is that you simply have to memorize where and when enemys spawn and when to jump. When I want to play a game, difficult or not, I do NOT want to memorize everything! I just want the opporturnity to play through with my skill, not because I know that I have to jump in 3,4 seconds. Too bad this game equals difficult with unfairness, at least in my opinion. I get it, there are many gamers who want an expierience like in the classic 80's NES-era platformers, but in my opinion this just doesn't fit today as it did back in the day. Retro gaming in general can be very good and a lot of fun but memorizing whole levels is just a sign for bad leveldesign. It always has at least to be possible to play the game through all by your skill. Due to the design choices overall the game feels kinda dated.Hence this game really doesn't cost much I still recommend to try it out for yourself and probably you will like it better than me.

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												Here's the thing with the golden age of arcade gaming... you could put a coin in to continue in games like Double Dragon, Golen Axe, Conbatribes, Ninja Combat, Bad Dudes, Contra, Final Fight, and Sengoku...  The only platform combat title I remember being so unforgiving as to send players back to the beginning was Shinobi, and nobody played that game in the arcade when they could just play it at home on their new sega system.  This should have a free-play or coin-op mode if it wants to style itself as an arcade game.  Everything in the game seemed to be an exercise in rote learning, which is the sort of thing that I only really enjoy when practicing a musical instrument.   I got my trading cards, and now I'm unstalling.

number of helpful: 6 of 13 people (46%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 30, 2015
												If you want a good challenge them I would recommend this game. Otherwise you're probably going to play for about an hour and then give up on it. I just feel like a game should be more rewarding than this. At least Ghosts N Goblins had cool spells you could unleash when you manage to grab a full set of powerups. Volgarr only manages to give you a triple damage spear with the first power up, and the final power up? A double damage sword. Not sure why the sword would end up being weaker than a powered up spear, but alright. Another mechanic that's frustrating is the inclusion of all these nice golden items, gems, etc.. But, Sonic the Hedgehog fashion, you lose about 75% of your treasure when you die. I have no idea if you can use your gold to urchase upgrades between levels, but I very much doubt it. It just seems like a pointless and not-very-rewarding mechanic to me. Another point of confusion is the checkpoints. On the first level you're given one after a very easy area. Then you're given one halfway through the level. You want one before the boss? Nah. Forget about it. There is, of course, a door that closes before you reach the boss. This seems like a mechanic borrowed from the Mega Man series, but makes no sense to have it here without a boss checkpoint. It would have made more sense if extra lives were involved, but instead you have unlimited continues and VERY few checkpoints. I would have preferred an Extra Lives system, having to restart an entire level when you run out of them, and more checkpoints. It's not all bad though. The combat mechanics and the art style (aside from a few out-of-place goofy looking enemies, like the smiley 'Joker' snakes in Level 1)  are both mostly very cool. It's too bad most players won't get to see all the art the game has to offer.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 25, 2015
												Yes, this game is in fact difficult and I am sitting here admitting I quit. I wimped out and quit. But, I am one of those that feels it is "cheaply" or "artificially" difficult rather than a fun challenge of any sort. What ever helps me sleep at night I suppose! I am a glutton for punishment and enjoy a challenge but this wasn't a game that I felt compelled to put in the 100th attempt of a level unlike other games. This game is pure memorization with no forgiveness whatsoever. Perfection or bust. Each hit you take has a devastating affect on your chances of completing a level to the point you may as well reset rather than push on. And with fairly clunky and stiffffff controls this is a recipe for a nightmare. In particular I will whine about the jump mechanics. Sure its subjective but I, personally, found the jump control atrocious. I suppose I should say LACK of jump control. You jump straight up and down or a predetermined distance. Timing the double jump adds a hint of control but not enough, for me. This is just one small factor in the overall issue; it's a grinding unforgiving challenge. Which isolated, is fine. But it just plain isn't a fun game during your punishment. I can enjoy a game that endlessly punishes you and makes you try something over and over. But I can't enjoy that beating if it isn't smooth and fun in the meantime. Put a little sugar on my beating.I forced myself to put in an effort for over an hour because of ego or some other stupid personality defect. But honestly the writing was on the wall five minutes in. I knew this game just wasn't for me and still knew that another punishing hour later. Looks and sounds neat at least. So that's something? I polished off my experience with the game by watching a speedrun and feeling shame about my gaming abilities. With a gruff "I'm too old for this shh" I uninstalled it forever. I'd suggest considering spending money elsewhere.A full congratulations to those who enjoy this game and the very very few that actually conquered it.

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 17, 2015
												An alright "retro styled" platformer; but a very poor imitation of an arcade classic.I'll put it this way: RASTAN, a coin guzzling monster of an arcade machine made in 1987, a game which this one desperately wants to copy, is far more forgiving, fair and balanced than Volgarr. The absurdity of that staggers me. I cannot think of a worse example of nonsensically exaggerated "Nintendo Hard" difficulty - a recent idea which is purely the product of people's dim memory of the past and laziness.You can't blame this game's poor design choices on anything but the creators' inability to recognize and recreate the good aspects of something they sought to imitate. It's not "oldschool" to have ridiculously long stretches between checkpoints or rely on poor placement of annoying enemies to challenge the player, it's just plain bad. Try harder next time, guys.On the positive side, the graphics and animation are fairly pleasing (if inconsistent) and combat is generally satisfying. I honestly want to praise this game just for aspiring to be like Rastan (which was long overdue for a proper tribute); but the more I play it, the more it infuriates me. Just get one of the many excellent Taito arcade collections instead.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
												Volgarr the Viking aims to be an old-school tough-as-nails platformer. Volgarr is a fellow that looks more like a norse barbarian than a viking to me, his jumps are stiff and you're so badass that enemies take 1-3 hits (bosses not included) to kill. These said monsters keep coming up all the time so you better move since they won't run dry. The gameplay reminds a bit of old NES game Trojan in a not so positive way (oh the slow walking, oh the stifness of my actions).You can hit, jump, point your sword downwards while jumping, do a sort of a double-jump by slashing in mid-air and throw a javelin that also works as a platform for you. You can't change direction or control the jumping much so better not spam it too much.Then the straight-up bs part: Volgarr attempts to  be hard. Real hard. IT sure is difficult but the difficulty comes from mistakes you make over and over again while playing the same part until you get it right and move to next nasty room. This TOO is usual, nothing too bad. BUT. Everytime I died I felt that "was that something I should've guessed?" or "if the controls were any better this could be easily done". Both of these could be dismissed as a bad player ranting but I've done my share of hard platformers like Ninja Gaiden, Battletoads, 100% completed Meat Boy and went through Spelunky without serious problems to name a few.Worst part is that the gameplay feels so clunky that I don't want to get accustomed to it. Good parts: -Window closes quite fast when quitting the game.

												OK well this game was not that hard, I am used to playing hard games, and this was not hard at all... I love retro games and I love a chalenge i.e I love Ghouls 'n' Ghosts... Ghouls 'n' Ghosts this is not. Volgarr opens and its so freaking epic, then you try and jump and realise the controles are broken and stiff You cannot steer yourself in the air as you can in a mario or metroidvania games for instance, the game is not hard just unfair with cheap deaths, crappy controle and slow as a snail movement.However everything ellse is excelent, animations are awesome, music is cool, and the art style is rich with detail. I hate to give negative reviews, but I will not blow smoke up this games cheap broken♥♥♥♥♥  I could have lived with no continues or save feature or password screen, that is 100% cool... even the cheap deaths also cool, but when your freaking hero cannot jump properly and the reason I died 97 times in a row is because of the jumping mechanic is broken, well that calls for a thumbs down. No excuses for this, the only reason this game is hard is because of that stupid freaking jump, and I refuse to re-learn how to jump in a game because the devs thought it was funny. This could have been such an awesome game, it's a shame a real shame... However if you are looking for something to make you pull out your nose hairs then this might be for you.

												This game captures the amazing nostaligic feeling of feeling absolutely crushed. If you are a very masochistic person who enjoys being repeatedly violated over and over again, I could not recommend this game enough. Volgar the Viking will make you question your life decisions. The control is tight, the level design is compact and intuitive, the enemy design and placement is creative, and Volgar's abilites are interesing and unique. However, a specific mechanic in this game can be either very fun for you or make you want to just uninstall this game and never look back. The fact that you will have to die so many times to learn patterns of enemies, where the pitfals are, how to defeat a certain part. It is an exercise in trial and error. That maybe what you want. But if you are looking at this game as a 'small little challange' then be forwarned, "abandon all hope ye who enter here".

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2016
												Have you played a game recently and thought to yourself "I don't know why this game has checkpoints or allows you to even save at all!!! I think you should have to start from the beginning everytime you play! This game is for BABIES!!" If you have then Volgarr is the game for you. It's a good game that's very hard and is fun (sort of for a sitting or two). The controls are a little on the stiff side. You cant steer yourself in the air as you can in a mario game for instance. This game seems to be trying very hard to make itself the new Super Ghouls 'n' Ghosts. It succeeds on that front for better or worse.See the game has checkpoints technically speaking. They cut the level in half into about 10 minute sections. That's not much of a checkpoint. What you do in effect is play the earlier parts of the game to absolute perfect in order to get another chance at something you might be struggling with. Is that hard? Yes it's absolutely hard to spend 10 mins doing things you are flawless at to have another go at the boss. Is it good game design? Uh... well....No (real) checkpoints, No saves, not even an old time password system for nostalgia. Brutal difficulty that requires and insists upon repetition, perfection, and memorization. Old school hard that makes a man out of ya or antiquated game design that is not a part of most modern games for a reason? You decide. I already have.One last thing. If you like this game and it's your jam then that's cool and good. It's good at what it does. You should check out Rastan. It's very very similar and I think it might be better so check it out if you like this game.

												Similar to Dark Souls: Prepare To Die Edition. Game is hard but never not fair. You just play and learn patterns, enemies movements and they attacks.This game reminded me old school Sega Genesis games: 2D, side scroller, moving from left ot right, some secrets, no saves and checkpoint only and each map start. So if you die at boss you'll have to start over the whole level.Almost forgot... You have infinite lives on "normal mode" (although if you die you loose some gold which is just a score in this game). However if you try to go for hard mode (before entering a new level go to it through Valkyrie statue) you have limited lives which you can collect when u have full gear (shield, helmet, flame sword) from the chests. Loose all your lives and you get teleported to "normal mode". If you die on last 7th level (Yggdrasil) with your last live then it's game over... Not game over but Ending B.. Which for me is still game over...

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												I wanted to begin this by setting the stage- you will die. You will die a lot. You will die so much, that this stage I'm setting is actually made of the corpses of the many failed attempts you will have playing this game.Volgarr is the only Viking I know that dies to a bee stinging him simply because he doesn't have a shield. On that same note, he's also the only Viking I know but that's irrelivent...The game is made to be hard. You get gear through the game that act as "hit points" for you, where if you get hit you'll lose your shield or your helm. If you lose it all Volgarr will explore into meat giblets if a stiff breeze kicks up. HOWEVER. There is a great deal of satisfaction to actually beating the game and beleive me when I say I memorized the entire first level before I was able to get the boss in one sitting...Keep in mind, this game has checkpoints but they don't save.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 7, 2016
												This game is manly!What can I say about this game? It's just perfect in it's own way. From the presentation, right down to the gameplay. And let's not forget one of the most epic soundtracks I have ever heard. Perfect for fans of Conan The Barbarian, and that old fasioned hard core difficulty of the 90s.This game will put hair on your chest! The level design might look bland from a distance, but when you're in the thick of it, it's perfectly designed around all of Vulgarr's moveset. It'll test your metal with obstacles that require perfect timing of double jumping, quick thinking to get out and around traps, and sword play against enemies that are all completely unique from one another.And, depending on your level of skill, there are 3 different endings to find. If you can't handle playing the game in one sitting, you can skip ahead to levels you played, before you actually take on the final boss to get ending C. For ending B, once you've had some practice, take on the game for real and play all the way to the end. For ending A, you're going to have to pump up and get some hidden collectables that'll act like lives to play through a completely alternate path. So there is a lot of replayability with this amazing game, that you should definitly start playing right now!

content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												I played quite a bit of this, so I feel I should leave a review. I believe that there is a very fine line between challenge and tedium. Personally, this game leans a bit too far into the tedium arena. Checkpoints are few and far between, and the enemies and bosses are unforgiving. Your survival depends on your ability to spam the level until you learn what obstacles lie ahead and know how to overcome them. It's all about prediction.Basically, if you like doing the same levels over and over and over and over and over and over and over until you learn them inside-and-out, this game is for you. If you do not, you will find this game to be the definition of tedium and you will simply not like this game. It was built with the hardcore challenge audience in mind. If you do not consider yourself a member of this audience, do not buy this game because it caters perfectly to them.Other than that, I feel there are a few areas that just felt cheap.
