content:
Posted: November 7, 2015
CASUAL GAMERS NEED NOT APPLYIf you like being kicked in the balls playing a really difficult game (and we're talking Super Ghouls & Ghosts difficult), then this is the game for you!No health bar, cumbersome control, lots of cheap hits, and enemies that can move faster than your character are the name of the game here. It is brutally difficult, and I have to say that it isn't to the game's credit. Retro gamers will be reminded of the game Rastan, in that in both games you control a barbarian-type character who attacks with a sword while (mostly) walking to the right. But whereas Rastan is a game that you can learn from, Volgarr the Viking isn't. This is mostly due to the fact that when you die, you go back to the last checkpoint, and checkpoints in this game are few and far between. Your character starts with a sword for his main attack, a spear for distance attacks and for climbing up walls, and a shield for defense, which can deflect some projectiles and that you lose after taking a single hit. If you're lucky, you can find a treasure chest that will first upgrade your shield (I have no idea what this does because you lose the upgraded shield after one hit -- it doesn't go back to the normal shield, mind you, it just goes away like the regular shield), then upgrade you to a helmet (that will take an additional hit, bringing your hit points up to two, after which you die), and a flaming sword that I presume increases your attacks (I don't know because I lost the flaming sword every single time after I got it on single-hit enemies).The graphics are pleasant to look at in a 90s arcade sort of way, and the sound is certainly up to par with titles in that vein, but that's about all I can say in its favor.Now, I'm occasionally up for a side-scrolling platforming challenge: I've beaten Super The Empire Strikes Back on the SNES, every version of Bionic Commando on every system it was ever made for, Strider on the Sega Genesis and quite a few of the NES Mega Man games. Maybe it's my old age setting in, or maybe I'm just tired of developer B.S., but I'm really starting the hate the kind of cheap, artificial challenge some of these modern platformers are offering by making the game so unforgiving. I've played the game for about two hours, and I've only ever gotten to the second checkpoint (not even the end of the first stage, if there are more stages). Oh yeah, and you have to start the game from the beginning every single time you quit the game and restart, so you'd better get good at those first few areas. I was really looking forward to this game and now I'm just angry that I've purchased it.If masochism and self-mutilation are your thing, then by all means: Go for it! Anyone who just wants to play a fun, challenging platform game can spend their money on Spelunky, Shovel Knight, Axiom Verge, or any of the dozens of other titles on Steam that are more rewarding, more forgiving, and certainly more fun.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
												If you're looking for oldschool gaming this title will not let you down. Solid controls, solid mechanics and gameplay, no BS and a great atmosphere will scratch that itch for a good challenge-reward experience. I can think of very little to say in detriment to this title, the best of which maybe a lack of checkpoints and a fairly unintuitive savepoint system (you go left, as indicated by a hint but go figure, it took a while to get how this feature worked properly). Overall this is not a timesink game. I certainly could be if you're into speedruns as it offers the necessary mechanics but aside from that it's a game that you gradually learn and progress through pretty much all based on player skill. Highly reccommended!

content:
Posted: May 7, 2015
												Horrible design choice ruins this gem of a game for me. It highly relies on learning from your own mistakes but not in a fair way. You will die at every new trap and will have to restart your whole tedious run again. As i remember, Ghosts'n Goblins had more frequent checkpoints and better lives system, which made it more friendly for practice and highly adaptable, depending on your skill in genre. In Volgar there's more "puzzling" approach to every obstacle, which you have to memorize after. Its pretty nice but done wrong, intentionally killing you no matter how good you are.mechanics is what made this game great for me, interesting spear platforming system, rolling, shield blocking, a bit clunky but adaptable jumping and etc. Really easy to get into but hard to master. I wouldn't mind level editor for this, as i see really huge potential for custom levels here.So, intentionally unpolished doesn't mean it's still not unpolished. I would like if they added easier mode, so players could adapt to game faster, and only then try their best on 1-life run. I think this is the only fair way, as i got bored pretty quickly from getting to the first boss on my first try without any hits and constantly dying from him, only to start from the beginning. I can take the challenge, but not when it has this tedious feel to it. Dev responded somewhere on the forum, saying that this would ruin the whole "get armor-get better" idea and blah blah blah, I don't mind grinding 1 boss with only my weakest shield instead of full armor set, i think it's better than playing the whole level you already mastered because of some little mistake you can't get.

Posted: June 13, 2016
												Volgarr the Viking is a sidescroller reminiscent of old NES games like Ghosts N' Goblins, and also brings back memories of good old games, like Zelda II and Hudson's Adventure Island.My hats to the developers for that.Still, this game wasn't for me. Some people will love it, but the game is just plain tough, and every time you die, you go back to the beginning. That was fine back in the 8-bit days, but times have changed, and I think this style of game has been redone better by games like Rogue Legacy and Binding of Isaac. With Volgarr, I'm frustrated because I'm dying because the controls didn't behave the way I wanted them to, or because you can't duck and throw a spear at the same time. You might love it, but not me.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2015
												Before I dive into this, let's establish something first. Odds are you probably haven't owned a car your whole life, right? I can assume you've had to walk to a store, or work, or the brothel, or your probation officer, or any place where you would much prefer some form of transportation that doesn't need to be tied to your feet first, right? You've also probably ridden in a car at some point in your life and I doubt you've ever found yourself thinking, "Gee, I sure do miss walking along the highway, dodging beer bottles being thrown by lucky but evil ♥♥♥♥♥", right? I would guess not. So let's get something straight. Going back to a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ era will most likely end with ♥♥♥♥♥♥ results. Can we all agree on that?With that in mind, here's yet another game that totally would have shined through the vast sea of♥♥♥♥♥♥known as late 80's/early 90's video games, had it indeed been released on the Sega Genesis like it wishes. Which is an alright ambition, but when rubbing elbows with modern games, it only reminds us why the Sega Genesis was so ♥♥♥♥♥♥ and why the mistakes of that era must never ever be repeated.Sure, there are plenty of games that do the whole 'retro thing', mostly because the people that can truly appreciate it are also old enough to have jobs, and wives, and children, and mid-life crisises, and most importantly; disposable income. But those are all just 'retro games', not 'games that take it too far by recreating all the♥♥♥♥♥♥everybody has been collectively trying to fix and forget about for the last 20 years because it's so ♥♥♥♥ing depressing to think that was the best form of entertainment we had for the first quarter of our lives'.In other words, games like Shovel Knight, are modern games with retro graphics. Voltardo the Viking, on the other hand, is not modern. How can I tell? Well, the controls for one. You better be damn sure you know which direction you want to jump prior to jumping or♥♥♥♥♥♥just isn't going to work out for you. Why? Because you can't change direction in mid-air and, when you die, you start back at the beginning and have to slowly waddle your way through the whole level all over again. In fact, let me start a new paragraph for that one because I know there are mindless, drooling ♥♥♥♥♥ that can't be asked to pay attention through a whole 3 sentences.You can't change direction in mid-air. Even if it's some sort of last ditch effort to avoid something that just spawned on the edge of the screen. And every time something does, it's too close and too late for you to react mid-jump. It's the exact same problem Vectorman had; the difficulty of the game is centered around the fact that you can't see anything farther away than♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥distance. But it's worse with ♥♥♥♥♥rr the Virginling because you're nearly defenseless while you're jumping and the only thing you can do is hit the attack button and hope for the best.To clarify, when you jump, you only jump straight up and down, OR angled in a predetermined, unchangable arc. Never a mixture of the two. Once you jump, you relinquish all control over to the wrinkly,♥♥♥♥♥♥stained hand of fate and hope it's nice enough to let you land where you wanted. That's right folks, it's a platformer with ♥♥♥♥♥♥ jumping controls. And I don't mean accidentally ♥♥♥♥♥♥, like you might find in some very low level indie games. No, this kind of douchbaggery took skill. They have clearly spent a lot of time playing ♥♥♥♥♥♥ late 80's/early 90's platformers and successfully recreated the very same controls everybody was rushing to debug. I don't know how to follow that one up. I'm flabbergasted, really. Somebody intentionally recreated the '♥♥♥♥♥♥ platformer with ♥♥♥♥♥♥ jumping controls' genre and expects to be taken seriously. This is exactly the kind of grade A, choice cut ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t we've been struggling to overcome for the last 20-30 years. And they recreated it. I almost respect it in that anarchist sort of way.What's even more baffling are the people who gave it enough positive reviews to earn it a total score of "very positive". Are you ♥♥♥♥ing kidding me? Were games like Half-Life 2, the Borderlands series and pretty much all games that show any semblance of progress since Meatloaf stopped being popular getting too boring for you? Yeah, who the hell would want to play a game that's fun and entertaining when we can play games that herald back to a time when every ♥♥♥♥ing game on the market, EVERY ♥♥♥♥ING GAME ON THE MARKET, would rub♥♥♥♥♥♥in our eyes then yell at us for 90 minutes straight because our eyeballs smelled like♥♥♥♥♥♥ Hell, why stop there? Why not build yourself an outhouse and start wiping your♥♥♥♥♥with corncobs while you're at it? Don't buy your butter from the grocery store anymore, churn it yourself. Want a salad? Start growing yourself one. Hell, here's a challenge if you want one so damn bad, try chasing your food down, pelting it with rocks and sticks for 3 days straight before finally eating it raw. Then when you're thirsty, try walking 8 or 9 miles to the closest stream and take a big gulp of bug, parasite and deer♥♥♥♥♥♥infested water.I will never understand this generation of entitled ♥♥♥♥tards who think "too easy" is a bad thing. Do you know how many people throughout time have wished for that kind of problem? Gonad the Ballbarian is the kind of fappery that isn't worth the time and money it takes to play or make, even if it is for the sake of all the people who feel bad about having♥♥♥♥♥♥too easy. If they want to suffer, let them buy an NES, a handful of random NES games and watch as they rage themselves into a coma. They'll all find out on their own why "too easy" is a problem you WANT to have.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2015
												Avoiding repitition is something I was taught very early in game design. The human brain gets tired of the same stimulus over and over, so especially in this medium, you want to make sure you're constantly presenting the player with new concepts and ideas as time progresses. It's a matter of respecting the player's time, you see. Games like The Binding of Isaac always make you feel like you're getting something for your trouble, and the only reason Super Meat Boy gets away with being Super Meat Boy is because you respawn almost instantly, and the levels are so small to begin with. If you die, they don't make you start the whole world over. The brain trust behind this game didn't understand this.Volgarr the Viking is the worst, and not for the reasons its creators think it is. I'm bored out of my frigging skull playing this game, because my fault or not, I'm sick of doing the exact same thing over and over. Even games like Devil May Cry manage to be tolerable because the gameplay is so deep that mastering it is the reward in itself, but Volgarr can't even manage that. It feels like nothing worthwhile is waiting for me no matter how far I get, aside from having to put up with more intentionally awful knockback and jump mechanics that make the game far less enjoyable than it should be. Surprise: design concepts abandoned by the rest of the industry over a decade ago aren't relevant in the current landscape anymore. This game was outdated before it was even released, and contrary to popular belief, that's not a good thing.

content:
Posted: January 23
												Don't be fooled by anyone saying this is a "love letter to NES platformers." I mean it is, but it's marred by questionable design choices that makes it fall far short of what it is trying to imitate.While the character controls great, a mix between NES and SNES platformer agility and attack-capabilities, it is a bit tedious having to execute the spin-attack + a down-slash in midair on almost every enemy; I really wish I could just hit dudes normally, as when I get to, it's very satisfying.But the major, crippling, FATAL FLAW of this game is the health system. You die in two hits. Not even legendarily hard games like Castlevania for the NES were that unfair; in that game, the final third of the levels you take four hits to die, and even that is brutal. But in this game, you take two hits from the very first level, and you're dead. The reason I say this game is a bad "love letter" is because I can't think of any NES game that was this unfair with the exception of some incredibly awful ones like Silver Surfer.You *can* get power-ups which will eat some damage and give you effectively a larger health pool but... these powerups go away when you get hit, which is SO unfun. I hate getting weaker the lower on health I am; it feels like throwing salt in the wound. You know that satisfying instinctual feeling you get when you get power-ups? Now negate it and double it, and that's what getting hit feels like.Also, you can only save between levels; if you shut the game off, any checkpoints you got go away. And it can take an hour or more just to get one checkpoint, so forget making any progress in this game unless you have hours to beat the entire level. Honestly, this might be an even bigger flaw than the amount of health you get; if I could save the game at mid-level checkpoints when I stop playing, then maybe I'd be able to make progress, but as it stands, unless you can beat an entire level in one sitting, be prepared to replay a LOT of BRUTALLY hard levels.If this game gave you more health, like six hits, this game would immediately become insanely fun, but as it was designed, it's unplayable. It demands ABSOLUTE PERFECTION 99% of the time. You think I'm exaggerating, but every enemy is deviously placed such that you have to beat them perfectly, because taking a hit from them is not an option with only two health.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2014
												Volgarr the Viking is one of the very best action/platformers ever made so go buy it now.Still reading instead of adding it to your cart? okay perhaps a bit more convincing is needed for some reason. I agree with those who say it's a bit reductive to compare games to fusions of other well known titles, but here it's perfectly applicable as Volgarr is what you'd get by combining Ghosts & Goblins with FromSoftware's Souls series. The Ghosts & Goblins influence is felt immediately not just by the slower, more deliberate pacing, but also by the nonrefundable jump arc, once you jump you're committed to it with only a double jump to save you from a poorly timed one. At the same time Volgarr conjures the spirirt of the souls series by teaching gamers through death and punishing failure as it's primary tool and while countless games have done the same thing years before any souls game existed Volgarr mirrors the souls games emphasis on combat and environment awareness. Learning each enemy's attack and movement pattern while avoiding stage hazards is the core of the game so if you rush your way through it without being as patient and methodical as the game wants you to be then "you're gonna have a bad time". That being said if you accept the fact that you will die a lot and manage to not throw your controller or keyboard through your monitor, then eventually some of Volgarr's badassery will transfer to you with that percentage growing as you master the mechanics and start feeling the flow of the game. Each chest adds an extra piece of armor to your arsenal depending on what you already have equipped while getting hit knocks off a piece so don't get hit if you want to keep your gear. No one is scared of a naked viking...my apologies to the naked viking communities of the world , but c'mon you know a flaming sword and metal shield can't ever hurt...well at least not you!If you're sick of the AAA, casual friendly, hand holding of modern games that think you're incapable of coloring inside the lines then pick up Volgarr the Viking and be reminded that some games still respect your reflexes and intelligence as a gamer.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2016
												Basically put, most players won't make it to the 3rd checkpoint. This game is so hard, it isn't even fun. Don't spend your money on this. Less then 75% of players complete the first mission on this game. Let's look at some statistics. Only 24.6% of players have even unlocked the achievement for completing the Lizard King Boss Fight. And only 54% of players have earned the achievement "The power of gray-skill" which is where you earn the flaming sword. That is the most commonly earned achievement, and only 50% of players have it. That means 50% of people won't even unlock a single achievement on this game, yet alone complete a single level. Achievements are the best example you can use, because they start being tracked once you actually play the game. If you purchase a game and just let it sit in your library, your achievement stats won't be tracked. So that means, once again, that less then 75% of active players will even beat a single level.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2016
												Precision action platforming with janky but predictable controls. This is probably something I would have played and gotten into when I was 7 years old, paid for a rental, and didn't have any other choices for games, but at this point the platforming isn't really that rewarding or fun for the number of times you'll die. Every time you lose you think you have to train yourself to be a better robot, pushing the buttons more precisely at the right times without error. With no additional gameplay mechanics or bells or whistles or draws to the game I can call this a pretty pure example of the "realtime precision button pressing" genre. That should be a steam game tag so I know to avoid it in future purchases.As someone else stated, you will either waste a lot of time on this game trying to prove you are hardcore or be done with it in 15 minutes. I can't help but think all the wannabe badasses who love this game are under 21, bored, and competing in their own version of an arm wrestling contest with Internet strangers OR are maybe prone to crying out at night "I'm too weak! I'm too weak!" while engaging in self flagellation to toughen themselves (i.e. their fingers) up. I also give this game one finger up.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2015
												Not impressed. I get it that everyone goes crazy any time anyone tries to make a NES-style 90's action game. I also get it that anytime I game specifically labels itself "hard" and uses archaic design or poor level/mechanic design to have you die all the time and constantly repeat the same parts over and over so you waste your life, just to beat one part to feel good about yourself, people go crazy as well and love it. Although old games were fun, there were reasons some mechanics were advanced, people they sucked but they didn't have the ability at the time to improve them due to specification limitations and technology. This game nails the early 90's look. The character feels super clunky and can only jump 1 inch. He can't aim and only knows how to look and shoot forward, and for some inexplicable reason once he's crouched he loses the ability to throw spears. All this makes him frustrating to play with. Also the jump attack is worthless. If someone jumps over at you and you try and jump to hit them, since they are way higher than you and you can't aim, you automatically get hit and can't do anything about it. Also if you attack a guy and he has more than 1 hitpoint, he can hit you while he is taking damage, which makes no sense, because if someone was slashing you with a sword you probably would have to react to that first before attacking. There are other things like how you throwing a spear actually moves you forward in the game. If you quit you have to restart the level/world over again. There was one part in the first level where there is this small jump with spikes below it, but because you can barely jump you aren't able to make it and have to just keep retrying it, dying, and starting everything over again. Poor design. Also you have can take one hit, no health or lives. you can pick up armor to mitigate damage, so you may take 1-3 hits or so, but because of the design thats super easy, and its not fun starting over again. I never felt a death was my fault or because I didn't do something. It was always because I "couldn't" do something due to limitations and poor design. Now I know that tons of the "hardcore" people that wasted countless hours of their lives retrying levels may be butthurt I pointed a lot of this out, but that's just my opinion. I like being given the tools to succeed, not poor design forcing me to die countless times until I finally beat a part to fill up my self-esteem. But hey if that's for you then this game is just what you're looking for. 4/10.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2014
												Just adding my own 10 cents here. Normally i don't take time to review a game, but i love this one so much that i had to give it a positive vote.     The rumors are true, this is a difficult game, but it's not difficult in a cheap way.  The challenges are steep but fair.  There are no cheap tricks here like getting stuck on stairs (Castlvania).  And it never gets so difficult that getting through a certain area relies on luck as much as skill.  You will get better with time and the places that gave you fits will (in time) become your ♥♥♥♥♥ as your skill increases.      As much as i love this game, it's still just a notch or two shy of what i would call the perfect hack n slash platformer.  One, it would have been nice to have a standing upward attack as well as being able to raise my shield against attacks from above.  That aside, if your a hack n slash 2D platformer fan, this game is a must have for your library.

content:
Posted: January 31
This game is too easy.It is marketed as a good, difficult retro platformer with tight controls, as well as having a healthy dose of viking violence.Of those promised qualities, it delivered only in regards to viking violence, since it is neither good, nor difficult and the controls are decent at best.While this game has a lot of minor issues, I want to focus on what I perceive to be the root of all evil when it comes to this game: It's approach to difficulty and leveldesign.Difficulty in VolgarrHaving played through the first three levels of Volgarr and beaten what most players seem to consider this game's hardest boss on the way,I can honestly say that no single combat encounter, jump or platforming puzzle was even remotely close to being hard to pull off or figure out. Why then have I not completed more of the game in the time that I played it?Because checkpoints are so rare that you need to get past just about a million of those obstacles in order to reach one checkpoint.This makes Volgarr feel and play like a game of low to medium difficulty,that has had about 50-80% of it's checkpoints removed. This is not how you challenge players. It's how you make them bored out of their mind.Having to run through the motions ploughing through mindnumbingly boring and repetitive combat encounters, just to fail and die at the boss,is neither challenging, nor is it fun. It is aggravating and a waste of time.I just had a glance at the kickstarter page and last time I checked, an "insane" boss in a game for the "truly hardcore" took more than a couple of tries to beat.While I have beaten some hard games before, I am by no means just that good at video games.This game almost exclusively tests your patience rather than your skill.If you are into that fair enough, but I'm not. Leveldesign in VolgarrFrom what I can tell, there are 3 ways of trivialising pretty much all enemies in the game:-Crouch and slash with your sword.-Kill them from a safe distance using spears.-Make them seperate from their pack and come to you by using spears.That approach to enemy-placement may or may not be retro, that is for others to decide.What I do know is that it is boring, unimaginative, and repetitive.Enemy design is equally bad: With few exceptions, there are basically enemies that will jump at youand enemies that slowly lumber towards you.Both can only damage you by touching you.Needless to say, neither of them are challenging, fun, or interesting. By now you should be able to guess what I think about the platforming and puzzles,so I won't go into detail but instead confirm your suspicion: I strongly dislike them.ConclusionToday I read an old forum post of one of the developers statingthat he wanted a game that played exactly like the games of old rather than like a retro game with modern influences. That at least makes some amount of sense and explains,why the developers apparently refused to learn from more modern,but actually challenging games like "they bleed pixels", which released before volgarr and is vastly superior in every aspect.Avoid Volgarr and get "they bleed pixels" and/or "Wings of Vi" instead.

number of helpful: 15 of 36 people (42%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 14, 2014
												This game is not a fun game. Its a boring hard grind from start to finnish. The game tries its hardest to kill you in cheap ways, miss time a jump - dead, swing your weapon at the wrong time - dead, use the downward attack (doesnt work 25% of the time) - dead. Start from the beggining of the level and redo it all without any mistakes. If you get hit once on the way to the boss you may aswel restart. It tries to be hard for the sake of being hard which doesnt lead to an enjoyable experience. The game pads its length out by making you redo the levels everytime you die, this made sense back when we were all playing megadrive games and you couldnt save progress but this is 2014 and we have moved on from this artificial style of difficuilty. While the majority of games these days are far to easy and hold your hand through everything this game goes the exact opposite way and too far in that direction. Its hard because you have to remmember the location of every enemy and their attack pattern and the exact way to deal with that enemy in that location, the game is basically one long session of memorising trivial details and then carrying out those movements precisely each time. The game has a certain charm to its style and it can be satisfying when you finnaly defeat that boss you were stuck on. There is pretty much no story, your a viking, go forward and hit things, you pick up gear to take more hits and do more damage, get hit and you lose that gear. It tries to be somewhat of a 2d darksouls, but that game betters it in every concievable way, the game is hard to better portray its story not for the sake of being hard, the combat system far superior etc.Its a hark back to old style games which is fun for 30 minutes and then you remmember why you dont still play those games.

number of helpful: 2 of 9 people (22%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3, 2014
												I am sorry, I'm just not into this game. I think it is irritating that levels rarely have checkpoints and the only difficulty is aggressively high. Don't think, I'm a casual ♥♥♥♥♥ gamer. I like Demon's Souls and Dark souls and I am a huge fan of Super Meat Boy and Gothic. Volgarr however seems to remaster only the bad things from our NES era. Why do I have to go through half a level (that is already known to me and its walkthrough already goes automatic for me) only to encounter swift difficult moment that I am stuck in and die in few seconds? Why can't I pierce the wall of an enemy with my spear if they are out of the screen? There is a wall just on the next screen. Why is it so hard for a spear to find it? Controls are not as responsive as it is required for some ingame moments. You know, there is a reason why developers abandon these things. I want to be able to practice one difficult moment in the middle of the level only. I want to try different tactics, learn the patterns, but for every try I have to go through a long starting part of the level that I already know. Sine Mora has special mode that allows you to practice boss fights only.  Super Meat boy does not have checkpoints because each level is 30 seconds long (maximum). Volgarr is not that unique for me to be dragged through already experienced gameplay over and over untill some intense moment everytime I die. I am highly disappointed in this game.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2014
												This is a fun little throw-back to 16 bit games that were hard-as-nails and required you to memorize enemy patterns to win.  Volgarr the Viking succeeds well at this and there are many speedruns on YouTube that are fun to watch. Unfortunatley this is not necessarily my kind of game though - there is little thought to winning. It is just pure memorization.It can be a bit frustrating at times. I hate choosing whether to recommend or not for this particular title, because it is up to your preferences, really. Just know that you are not getting anything fresh here. It is a good reimagining of old-school side scrolling action games.

content:
Posted: March 25, 2014
												Apparently I have misunderstood the concept of tight controls mentioned often when this game has been discussed, but I don't feel  that having to stop frequently to do ranged attacks, not being able to change your direction mid-air (only when double jumping, how is that logical?) and constantly being knocked back by enemies is in any way a fluent way to control your character. I'd understand if you couldn't change your direction even when double jumping, but the current system does not bode well with my mindset of gaming canon. OFC I understand that knockback is herited from old platformers this game seems to be an homage to, but in my opinion, we could nowadays do well without that relic. Also I dislike the notion that you have to go back so much each time you die, but on the other hand many people might enjoy this challenge and in a way I did expect the game to have such a feature beforehand.

number of helpful: 11 of 29 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2016
												I know that Völgarr the Viking is supposed to emulate old-school hardcore platformers like Super Ghouls 'n' Ghosts and the like, but there are several things about it that I just don't like, and pretty much all of them are caused by that very blind emulation of by-now obsolete game designs.A big fat one that's definitely a dealbreaker AND right off the bat costs the game a recommendation, is the fact that it doesn't have a save function. And I'm not talkin' about a quick-save/quick-load function for those extra gruelling boss-fights. No, I'm talking about playing the game one day and making 3 hours worth of progress, and then being COMPLETELY unable to save said progress in order to start from THAT point at a later time.Seriously, Crazy Viking Studios. Do you honestly think that SGnG lacked a save function because they wanted to make the game atrociously frustrating to play? Or did it ever occur to you that maybe, just MAYBE, games back then simply didn't have save functions because they COULDN'T, due to extreme hardware AND software limitations?Another massive gripe I've got with VtV is the fact that you can't tweak the difficulty level to any degree, so you extra hard-to-the-core motherfûckers out there can't get an extra challenge by, say, spawning more enemies or make said enemies attack with greater precision, or anything like that. And you slightly more "casual" folks who really just wanna enjoy the game without restarting 20 times per minute will find it frustratingly unforgiving with a lot of really rather bullshïtty pixel-perfect-over-instant-death-gaps jumps.I will say though that the combat is good. Really good, frankly. It's easy to learn the controls, and all of the attacks and maneuvres you have are in some way useful, and throwing a fully powered up spear into a lizardman and then watching said spear continue to plow through 3 other reptilians fûcktards only to splatter them brutally against a wall is EXACTLY what being a badass viking warrior in a land of myths and legend is all about!I can't really say much for the entirety of the game, since the unforgiving nature of it always leaves me too fûcking frustrated to keep playing for very long, and thus I've never gotten very far into the game. If the game DID have some sort of an autosave function, so that you could continue from the last checkpoint you visited, I'd probably be inclined to give VtV a 9+ score. But as it stands, I really can't give it more than around half that, at best. So yeah. Sorry, Crazy Viking guys. You did your best, and I wanted to like your game, but it's just not as good as it NEEDS to be for that to happen. 4.6/10

content:
Posted: May 14, 2014
												What makes a game great? Difficulty? No. Progression and a sense of overcoming ever increasing challenges? Yes. Perhaps the developer wasn't trying to make a great game, perhaps he was, but bottom line, it's a BAD game.It's not hard to make a bad game. Consider this; let's take Diablo II, a game heralded as best of its genre even after all these years, could I screw that up? Easily, by tweaking something as simple as drop rates, or damage etc. Just look at Diablo III for proof. Thankfully, the PC game is a forgiving medium, look at what Aarkalash did, they made their easy mode easy. Volgarr has no different modes, and thus is such a niche game as to be inaccessible to the market. Folks that grew up playing games like Rastan (and still do) would find this offering a waste of time. Rastan is better. Why would I play Volgaar?Maybe buy this game for 50 cents. Maybe.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												Stay away! This game looks awesome based on the trailer, but it's cynically playing all the "so hot right now" cards that it can find (retro graphics, callbacks to 1980s and 1990s classic games, over the top machismo, etc) without ever deivering the quality to back it up. Volgar the viking s designed to be very, very hard, but the controls don't support that kind of gameplay. They feel sticky, they are laid out unintuitively (feeling very console-portish), and they are very poorl tutorialized. The game is also full of silly design flaws (if you crouch down, none of the lizard men on the first level can hit you - their clubs pass harmlessly overhead!). Add deliberately ridiculous difficulty to very poor controls and the game quickly becomes frustrating instead of fun. And I say this as someone who enjoyed both Dark Souls and Teleglitch! AVOID AT ALL COSTS.

Posted: May 16, 2014
												Very enjoyable, challenging old-school game. retro 16 (or 32) bit graphics. tight controls (though not perfect) and an addicting level of difficulty. My one qualm is that with the game's design, and thats THAT YOU CAN'T SAVE. Spend an hour getting past just the first level? Quit after spending a half hour on level 2? Well, bad news, because you'll have to start straight from the beginning with no saves or continues if you choose to quit the game (which any normal human will do, at some point or another). That's right, its just like an arcade game-- which is clearly the style this game succeeds at emulating-- no saves or continues once you stop playing. You get checkpoints, 1 per level, whilst you play, but once you quit that's it. I love the game, I really do, and I was lucky enough to get it on sale for less than $5.00, but I can't help but feel a little ripped off due to this single element of the game. That being said, some will thrive from the old-school challenge, experiencing deja' vu from the 80's-90's arcade era-- knowing that it's all or nothing. Once you stop playing or run out of quarters, you'll have to try again next time right from the start. For its challenge, controls, retro appeal, and sheer enjoyability, this game deserves an 8/10. The no-saves feature holds this challenging Castlevania-style game back from being a fully-fledged game. Again, some will really love that, but in these days where time is a constraint for most, its a nuissance.

												A lot of people say this game makes you memorize the level before you can beat it.  These comments are completely wrong.  The game and level design is great to the point of teaching the player all the dangers of a level before they will resonably die to them.  The rules are laid out plaining for anyone who is willing to pay attention. 												Who liked the sega genesis? Someone... I'm sure. Anyway, this game looks like a genesis game and plays like Castlevania. It's crushingly hard, as you would expect from a viking, but it's chock full of action, secrets, and characters with really great abs. MY abs were even toned by playing this game. Posted: January 25, 2014
												When you finish your first session of Volgarr, one thing becomes abundantly clear : Either you're in love or you've simply wasted your money.This game is extremely hard but manages to strike that balance between frustration and that wonderful feeling of accomplishment that only comes from punitive, hardcore games. If the level design and enemy behaviors weren't expertly handled I would've stopped playing a long time ago. Fortunately, this game is very precisely and masterfully crafted and I just can't put it down.There is no way around it, you will have to memorize enemy patterns, attacks and level layouts in order to progress.Getting hit means losing a power-up, just like in Super Mario Bros. While it is possible to keep trudging forward without these power-ups, it makes the game a whole lot trickierIf you manage to get through a level without getting hit, you get more Gold and a chance to play a bonus level. In this way, Volgarr forces you into Speedrunning. If you don't like old-school games where repetition and pattern mastery is obligatory, you will hate Volgarr.Super Meat boy is the most recent example of this kind of experience; It's a game which is hard but its pacing and level length / instant respawn was crafted to make sure that you'd give it just one more try before heading to bed. Once you cleared a level, it felt abolutely amazing. The same applies to Volgarr.At first, Volgarr evokes classics Altered Beast and Rastan; in fact, it could be argued that the first level is largely a re-telling of Rastan's first level. As the game progresses, you'll see some Mega Man, elements from Chakan : The forever man and even bits of QuackShot!This game is obviously targeted at old-school hardcore gamers; if you fit the description, I really don't see how you can not enjoy Volgarr. It is truly a modern classic masterpiece.

												To skip levels, you have to walk left not only at the title screen, but also at the beginning of each level you want to skip.  Also, if you hold the button down to throw a spear, you charge it up and it'll do up to 3x damage (only if you have the hammer shield power-up).  These are things the in-game tutorial didn't tell me, but would've been good to know going in.  Now you know.  The game is an obvious homage to Rygar, but is much better than it. Posted: April 10, 2016
												Yet another retro work that tries to emulate NES difficulty games. Does it succeed? For the most part, yes.The six worlds are split into two parts with only one checkpoint at the beginning of each part. You have infinite continues, but if you die at any moment in the middle of each part (including boss fights) you'll have to start over from the beginning of that part. Völgarr can slash with his sword, hurl spears at the enemies or on walls to climb them, roll and double jump with the second jump making him do a rolling sword attack a little like in SNES Star Wars games; the only tricky part is the jumping since he can only jump straight up or in diagonals and you cannot change the trajectory once you've jumped, but for the rest it's pretty easy to control.The game is entirely deterministic (except those damn blobs), which means that you can elaborate a safe pattern to reproduce each time you play the level. This definitely helps since the levels are pretty hard and you'll probably need to restart each section many times before you understand how to get past each enemy. It will take you 5 to 8 hours to beat it once depending on your skill.Hardcore players that manage to get to the end of the level almost unharmed will also be rewarded with five alternate paths (basically 5 harder levels with max 3 lives to finish them) and if they finish each one of them you'll get an extra level at the end.Recommended to those who seek for a small, challenging but manageable game.

Posted: July 18, 2015
												Take the enemy spawns of Castlevania, the platforming of the original Prince of Persia and the Gear-Based hit system of Ghosts and Goblins, throw a pinch of Viking awesomeness in that mix and you have Volgarr (though I'm pretty sure Ghosts and Goblins is still harder, I'm sure at least SOMEONE made sure more than 5 people could beat Volgarr.)This is a game that belongs to an age where you would get 1-3 video games a year as a kid and your option was love that game and get good at it, no matter how sucky or hard it was, or just go back to playing your old games. This is not a game you play casually to kill a few moments or to sit back and relax with. This is the kind of game that from screen one slaps you in the face and says, "I dare you..." This is the kind of game you brag about beating, put on your resume and call home and tell your mother about.The only thing that sets this game apart from an actual nintendo game is infinite continues and the forgiveness of not sending you back to the start of the game with every other death.This is not a game for the casuals. This is a game for champions. This is the game that if you beat, the Valkyries will descend from the heavens en masse and carry you off to Valhalla where you will be afforded seats of honor, the finest of meads and only the most worthiest of champions to do daily battle with!

Posted: July 10, 2015
												I like the game and most of the gameplay mechanics it involves.However, everything that I like is shadowed by a huge problem : the jump is bad as hell. I don't know what you guys did with it but it's pretty horrible... The jump works like this : you can jump one time then jump another time when you're in air - so that's a basic double jump. However, it doesn't work like a regular double jump... No no, it's like this : say you're going to the right and press jump once, your character will jump to the right. Now if you jump with a direction input while you're in air, your character will keep the same direction, which means that you cannot land precisely where you want... Yes I know, you can jump once in a direction then jump while in air with no direction input to land below... But to me, that's totally ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and it feels like jumping with a retard - I thought - and it really seemed - that Volgarr was badass like Ragnar, the ♥♥♥♥ is this♥♥♥♥♥♥seriously ? :sTLDR : I hate the jump mechanics, feels like Robocop trying to jump... and for this I cannot recommend this game although I like most of it, god I hate you guys !

Posted: July 10, 2015
												Summary: A well designed and polished 2D trick platformer for oldschool sensibilities.This game is difficulty, but its difficulty revolves mostly around learning the mechanics: movement, attack, level hazards and enemy behavior.The controls are reminiscent of NES Castlevania: in addition to a fixed-arc jump, there's also double spears, rolling and rope climbing. (Thankfully, no stairs!)Your offensive options consist of a sword and an infinite supply of spears, which can also be used as platforms.During a first playthrough, you ought to be careful and approach situations slowly, but as you start mastering the game, you'll be able to flow at a satisfying pace through the levels.Bosses are a matter of memorizing their patterns and finding the safe spots and the opportune times to strike.There are three ending to get, each requiring more of the player, but not unfairly so.The two additional endings raise the ante by requiring you to go through alternative stages on a limited supply of "lives," which you must earn by traversing the stages near flawlessly.Recommended controls: gamepad with a good D-pad and at least two buttons (ideally four, for pause and view toggle)(I played with a sideways Wiimote.)Pros:Easy to learn and difficult to masterTight controlsWell polishedGood replayability, with alternate levels, three endings, and a leaderboardMost achievements attained naturally while completing all endingsWell optimized. Runs well on humble hardware.Cons:No mid-session save feature. (Prevents save-scumming; inconvenient nonetheless.)Must-do:Go in the options and set the option "use look ahead as a toggle," otherwise you'll be hitting the look ahead button way too frequently.

Posted: December 27, 2013
												Oh man... Did you game in the 80s? Classic NES such as Ninja Gaiden and Wizards & Warriors? Do you love a game that is unapologetically tough (but not unfair)? Do you remember sinking quarters into Stryder? If the answer is yes, this game is totally for you. No save points, just check points. You die, you start the level over. Get to the boss and die? You start the level over. Quit the game? Start the game from the start. Never unfair or cheap, this game pushes you (much in the same way as Dark Souls but this isn't near the sadist/masochist relationship of that).I can't recommend this game enough for us in our late 20s to late 30s. This is the stuff we grew up on. A fantastic homage. If you like metal, it's like the Skeletonwitch/Havok/Municpal Waste of video games.MAYBE some of the youngins will join the club of tough games for toughness sake. And maybe we'll let them in. ;)

Posted: December 13, 2013
												This is definitely a game made for a small audience, and I'm super grateful to the developers for making it. You only ever have two weapons: a sword and a throwing spear. The sword can be used in a few ways and upgraded to a fire version (if you're good enough), but the real star of the show is the spear. Not only can it be used to attack enemies from afar (infinitely), but it can also be used to make platforms to stand on by throwing them at walls. And that's not just a fun gimmick... there are numerous chests out of reach through normal means until you find clever ways to throw spears and make paths to them.That's also how much of the battles unfold. It's not really a good idea to charge ahead and hope for the best so much as learn how enemies attack and make deliberate movements in order to vanquish them. The bosses work the same way too. Believe me, you'll die plenty of times fighting them, but each death helps you learn their pattern and once you know it, you can bring them down without taking a hit. Thank goodness for unlimited lives, eh?Just in case it isn't hard enough, there's actually a harder alternate version of each stage (with limited lives) that you can only get to by playing the previous stage near-flawlessly. And the only way to get the best ending is to do that for every stage.If you miss the good ol' days of fair but unrelenting difficulty, pick this sucker up.

Posted: November 12, 2015
												Volgarr was friggin' tough. It's one of those games you need to butt your head against until you just get good at it; no other way to put it. It takes the best of its inspirations, like NES Castlevania and Rastan Saga, and bundles it into a tight, challenging game. Also, there is appreciable thoughtfulness in enemy placement/levels are designed around enemy mechanics; which is always great to see. Awesome game, great job Adult Swim.

Posted: November 7, 2015
												SpoilersI have done my best to keep this review from spoilers so that readers can enjoy it without regretting reading it. As with food though, there might be some traces of "allergens".My experience of older gamesI grew up playing the Sega Master System, Sega Mega Drive, Super Nintendo (SNES), and Game Boy (first generation). I found it appropriate for me to write my first review on this particular game since it belongs to a genre that I hold very dear. The SNES console is my all time favourite game system.GraphicsVölgarr truly captures the feeling and aestethics of games of the past! People who have played a game called Rastan seem to recognise elements from that game and while I never played it, based on pictures on Google I see why. The enemies and levels are clearly inspired from that game.The graphics remind me, however, of another game which I think Völgarr resembles at least as much: ActRaiser II. This game was released on the SNES console and Völgarr's graphics are defenitely 16-bit. The character's poses, movement and moves and also the music and variance in level themes resemble in a way those in ActRaiser II.One thing that reveals Völgarr is a modern game is the background/the horizon which has been blurred to give a sence of depth. While the purpouse is obvious, I have never seen that in a 16-bit game and would have preferred graphics limited to the style of the time. Sence of depth was very well achieved in the old games too, but one pixel was one pixel and could never be blurred.GameplayThis game could easily have been published back in the early 90's. The character moves just like in a viking/swordsman/fantasy themed SNES-game: Relatively slowly, giving a sence of weight (muscles, armor, weapons and muscels). The attack moves are slightly delayed and need to be perfectly timed just like in the old games (if you remember games like Altered Beast you know timing is everything!)The controls are 2 buttons + arrows / 4 buttons + arrows depending on how you choose to play. if you want one button for each action, you go with 4. I chose to go with 2, which means e.g. that throwing a spear = UP + ACTION.Let's just lean back for a moment and enjoy the nostalgia...Right, let's continue!One of the main themes the developers advertise in the game trailer is dying. All of us who played NES, SNES, Game Boy, Sega Master System or Sega Mega Drive games know what it feels like to fail over and over and over again. It was so frustrating, yet addictive. You HAD to beat that level and you HAD to figure out what series of moves and attacks the boss had in order to beat him/her. Völgarr captures this beautifully! Just getting through the first level/world and beat the boss feels like conquering the world! (The developers of Völgarr have been kind though - back in the days you had often limited lives, limited "Continues", and sometimes no checkpoints at all!)After a while, when you decide to play the game all over again, you suddenly realise how good you've gotten at this game. You're wielding your sword and throwing spears as if you were born doing so. That moment made me smile - it really brings back memories...My thoughts (who am I kidding - you know what I'm gonna say!)I LOVE THIS GAME and anyone who grew up with or has ever happened to fall in love with 16-bit games in particular will too! I began this review feeling quite sophisticated but after writing this and realising how much I really like this game, I end up feeling like a kid on saturday morning - waiting for my best friend to come over for a sleepover with snacks and video games all night!I really have to try to fix my SNES console (showing black sreen of death)...

Posted: January 8, 2015
												This is a hard and unforgivable 2D platformer. You'll need to learn a set of rules as the behaviors of your ennemies, the topographie of the level and the effect of the different items you can find.You'll die a lot and restart at the last checkpoint, which doesn't last between game sessions (you'll have to restart from the start everytime you restart the game). In this game, you learn through experience and hard work. However, once you understand the game mechanics, you'll genuinely feel proud of yourself seeing your badass viking prolifically chop monsters away.

Posted: May 7, 2015
												It's okay, not as good as I was hoping.Volgarr the Viking is a very deliberately paced linear action-platformer. Think Castlevania 1 or 3.The distinguishing feature of this game is that it's pretty difficult due to some unusual, unforgiving design choices. For starters, you have no horizontal air control at all, like the old Castlevanias, though you have a double jump. There is also a surprising amount of recovery after landing a jump. In addition, you die after only 1-3 hits, and getting hit causes you to lose an entire tier of power-ups.The problem I have with the game is that it doesn't seem difficult in a particularly fun way. For example, at the very beginning you're going to die a ton just learning what you can block, enemy behavior, how to space jumps, and how to deal with enemies coming from above and below you. There's no real tutorial level to teach you the basics, which just means you're going to die a lot.On top of that, the health system is really brutal. The game basically rewards you hugely for playing perfectly by giving you a way better weapon and better defense, but as soon as you take any 1 hit you lose that advantage. It's a weird system, because the game essentially becomes harder the less good you are the game. If you're really good and can play levels perfectly, you'll coast along with a weapon that does double damage with extra range, better blocking, and which is faster, along with the buffer health. If you're imperfect, you have to make do with ♥♥♥♥♥♥ weapons/blocking.On top of all that, it's a very slow game, that's very low on improvization or surprises. Everything is very predictable, and the game moves at such a deliberate pace that it's principally a memorization/timing challenge.There are some cool moments in the levels, and the graphics have a really nice aesthetic, but it's just not a very fun game to play. It's very much a game about perfectionism, and it's just not really very fun to learn. I'm actually a big fan of the old, hard platformer castlevanias, and 2d action-platformers in general, but this game is just not a particularly good example of the genre.

Posted: April 1, 2015
												I've finally beaten this f***er! VOLGARR THE VIKING was probably made to torture people. I mean I literally was close to crying once after the hundredth-retry. I'm not kidding! Volgarr is hard, extremely hard... but not unfair. Every mistake you make is your fault, not the fault of the game. If i had to describe the gameplay of VOLGARR THE VIKING I had to choose this: A combination of CASTELVANIA, GHOULS AND GOBLINS and THE LEGEND OF ZELDA2 THE ADVENTURE OF LINK. Those 3 games combined but ten-times harder. And trust me it's difficult to make a game that is harder than GHOULS AND GOBLINS. Playing Volgarr is kinda like playing memory... on acid. If you would hand me a piece of paper and a pen I could draw a map for all the levels I've beaten, without looking it up. I know every bit of this game by heart and if you play it through you will too! So is Volgarr a good game? YES it is! If you are looking for a challenge, there you have one!Oh and buy a 2nd controller. You'll break one during your play through I guarantee it!

Posted: May 6, 2015
												If this were releaased on the SNES it wouldn't get a second look, the fact that we don't have side scrolling platformers anymore makes this a specialty product but that doesn't mean there's anything particularly special about it.It's a sidescrolling platformer; you fight enemies, get powerups that improve your attacks and armor but explode when you're hit, and eventually fight a boss at the end of each level.The game isn't too hard, you have to memorize patterns of enemies over long lengthy areas; jump when you need to, throw your spear when you should, and attack at the correct moment. The REAL BUMMER ARE THE BLOODY """"""CHECKPOINTS""""". The Checkpoints are FLIPPIN' MADDENING! and it's why you won't want to keep playing this game.LISTEN, I've beaten hundreds of NES games, hundreds of SNES games and yatta yatta. I presume you have also, or at least beaten a couple. If I rented this game in 1993, I would have played it for about an hour and taken it back to Blockbuster. I don't find it enjoyable, and I don't think it's worth your time.

Posted: May 6, 2015
												If this were releaased on the SNES it wouldn't get a second look, the fact that we don't have side scrolling platformers anymore makes this a specialty product but that doesn't mean there's anything particularly special about it.It's a sidescrolling platformer; you fight enemies, get powerups that improve your attacks and armor but explode when you're hit, and eventually fight a boss at the end of each level.The game isn't too hard, you have to memorize patterns of enemies over long lengthy areas; jump when you need to, throw your spear when you should, and attack at the correct moment. The REAL BUMMER ARE THE BLOODY """"""CHECKPOINTS""""". The Checkpoints are FLIPPIN' MADDENING! and it's why you won't want to keep playing this game.LISTEN, I've beaten hundreds of NES games, hundreds of SNES games and yatta yatta. I presume you have also, or at least beaten a couple. If I rented this game in 1993, I would have played it for about an hour and taken it back to Blockbuster. I don't find it enjoyable, and I don't think it's worth your time.

Posted: June 27, 2015
												Definitely my favourite platformer. It has tight controls, great enemy, boss and level design. Music gives a good atmosphere which gets you pumped and really puts you in the game. Controls are spot on, everything is responsive and just feels good. Jumping is quite tricky, no turning mid air except with the second jump, which creates difficulty in jumping if you are too hasty. It's not very hard to learn, atleast from my own experience, but satisfying to pull off well.Enemies are generally predictable from first sight, but still makes you work them into your muscle memory. They are all fair, and the tough ones are generally first put in a position where you will have an easier time fighting them, and after youve beaten them once they will re-appear later on but in a much trickier spot where it will make you really think more than just using what you learnt from fighting them the first time.Bosses can be tricky, but very manageable the first time around. They telegraph their attacks clearly and you can adapt to it if you have a good feel for these kinds of games.The level design is great because it always manages to make you use all of your tools, tricky doublejumps, spear throws and rolls. Not too many instant death pits, instead enemies will be the real threats. Enemy spawns are pretty much always the same, so memorizing them is great fun when youve gotten to the point of nearly speedrunning through levels, trying to get the best ending.Like mentioned theres also different endings, and by running through the game once the normal way a new player would, you fight your way through the basic maps and get the, well, bad ending. But if you beat a level while not getting hit too many times you will get Warrior spirits that take you to the same themed levels, but with a much harder design. This makes for a great second playthrough attempting to get the best ending by beating all the hard maps.

Posted: December 29, 2014
												When a store page uses words like "old school hard" or "brutal difficulty", I can see the appeal. Völgarr the Viking is hard in the same way that early entries in the Castlevania series are hard. Yes, it's not something that just anyone can pick up, play, and enjoy. No, this is not necessarily a good thing, but some players need that extra bit of a triumphant feeling in completing a level.   One thing that's clear from the very outset is that this is in no way one of those modern games that so many grognards accuse of excessive handholding. No, you're thrown right into the world from the beginning, with no direction but the innate instinct to go right. Be sure to check out the game's manual, too, as it explains a few helpful concepts that the game's (intentionally) meager tutorial might not make explicitly clear. Be sure to check it out, also, for the fact that it's a loving recreation of the kinds of manuals one finds packaged with (better) retro cartridge games, although black and white would have lent that extra sense of nostalgia.   The graphics are old-school only in the sense that there's a (relatively) limited color palette and movement occurs in only two dimensions, as you slash and spear your way through seemingly endless ranks of palette-swapped enemies of varying strength and ability. There's clearly a lot of love on display in the general and specific "feel" of it all.   Völgarr the Viking is absolutely not for everyone, and it never intends to be, but if you're of the kind who enjoys approaching combat as just as much of a puzzle in rhythm and positioning as the rest of the level, it might just be the game for you.

Posted: January 4, 2015
Volgarr the Viking is a platformer, beat-em-up game. It's the kind of game that brings back memories from the 8, 16, maybe even 32-bit era. It has many similarities to good old games such as Ninja Gaiden or Ghosts n' Goblins. Let me tell you one thing, if you like a challenge, this game is the game for you!Overall: I'd give it a 7.3/10. Its good, but I'm kind of put off by this game by multiple factors.Controls & Handling: 8/10. I used the Xbox 360 Controller for the game, and it was kind of awkward at first, using the joystick as movement. I prefer using the D-Pad and luckily, they added the option to! Some other controls are kind of weird like your double jumps acts as an attack move, so I keep on pushing my attack button in the air instead of my jump button, but that's my fault. Some tights spots that are downward are kind of iffy, but the Right Trigger also acts as a "Pogo Attack", so I'll leave it at that.Graphics: 6/10. The graphics are supposed to be two dimensional and blocky, reminiscent of the older times, but blood... blood everywhere. Sometimes unnecessarily large amounts of blood. In all honesty, it kind of puts me off.Storyline: To be honest, I couldn't get far enough to see if there was any storyline. It just made me so mad! It's really  challenging.Music: 8/10. It really fits the game, and it's viking theme. I don't know how to describe it... like... Nordic? Viking?

Posted: January 27, 2015
												From the outset I couldn't help but notice the similarities between this and the arcade classic 'Rastan'.  In places, the level design is pretty much a carbon copy.  Volgarr however is a significantly different beast.  The checkpoint restart system and unique moves set give this game an irresistible one more go replay value.  The difficulty level is set just right too.  You will die repeateatedly - very repeatedly - but you'll always know it's your own fault, and with a little practice everything is achievable. This is one of the main things that makes Volgarr so enjoyable.It's nothing special graphically, but this appears to be the intention.  The game's obviously going for a retro approach to the graphics, and to be honest it benefits from it.  It just wouldn't feel the same with slick, HD visuals.If you're still not sure, go check it out on YouTube.  If it looks like it appeals to you, you'll love it.

Enemies are placed and combat is designed to favor planning and strategy, akin to old Castlevania games, and it just feels good to slice opponents.I wish you could save between levels, sure when you die you get to restart, but I don't necessairly have time to beat it all in one shot. Posted: December 13, 2013
												This is definitely a game made for a small audience, and I'm super grateful to the developers for making it. You only ever have two weapons: a sword and a throwing spear. The sword can be used in a few ways and upgraded to a fire version (if you're good enough), but the real star of the show is the spear. Not only can it be used to attack enemies from afar (infinitely), but it can also be used to make platforms to stand on by throwing them at walls. And that's not just a fun gimmick... there are numerous chests out of reach through normal means until you find clever ways to throw spears and make paths to them.That's also how much of the battles unfold. It's not really a good idea to charge ahead and hope for the best so much as learn how enemies attack and make deliberate movements in order to vanquish them. The bosses work the same way too. Believe me, you'll die plenty of times fighting them, but each death helps you learn their pattern and once you know it, you can bring them down without taking a hit. Thank goodness for unlimited lives, eh?Just in case it isn't hard enough, there's actually a harder alternate version of each stage (with limited lives) that you can only get to by playing the previous stage near-flawlessly. And the only way to get the best ending is to do that for every stage.If you miss the good ol' days of fair but unrelenting difficulty, pick this sucker up.

Posted: November 7, 2015
												SpoilersI have done my best to keep this review from spoilers so that readers can enjoy it without regretting reading it. As with food though, there might be some traces of "allergens".My experience of older gamesI grew up playing the Sega Master System, Sega Mega Drive, Super Nintendo (SNES), and Game Boy (first generation). I found it appropriate for me to write my first review on this particular game since it belongs to a genre that I hold very dear. The SNES console is my all time favourite game system.GraphicsVölgarr truly captures the feeling and aestethics of games of the past! People who have played a game called Rastan seem to recognise elements from that game and while I never played it, based on pictures on Google I see why. The enemies and levels are clearly inspired from that game.The graphics remind me, however, of another game which I think Völgarr resembles at least as much: ActRaiser II. This game was released on the SNES console and Völgarr's graphics are defenitely 16-bit. The character's poses, movement and moves and also the music and variance in level themes resemble in a way those in ActRaiser II.One thing that reveals Völgarr is a modern game is the background/the horizon which has been blurred to give a sence of depth. While the purpouse is obvious, I have never seen that in a 16-bit game and would have preferred graphics limited to the style of the time. Sence of depth was very well achieved in the old games too, but one pixel was one pixel and could never be blurred.GameplayThis game could easily have been published back in the early 90's. The character moves just like in a viking/swordsman/fantasy themed SNES-game: Relatively slowly, giving a sence of weight (muscles, armor, weapons and muscels). The attack moves are slightly delayed and need to be perfectly timed just like in the old games (if you remember games like Altered Beast you know timing is everything!)The controls are 2 buttons + arrows / 4 buttons + arrows depending on how you choose to play. if you want one button for each action, you go with 4. I chose to go with 2, which means e.g. that throwing a spear = UP + ACTION.Let's just lean back for a moment and enjoy the nostalgia...Right, let's continue!One of the main themes the developers advertise in the game trailer is dying. All of us who played NES, SNES, Game Boy, Sega Master System or Sega Mega Drive games know what it feels like to fail over and over and over again. It was so frustrating, yet addictive. You HAD to beat that level and you HAD to figure out what series of moves and attacks the boss had in order to beat him/her. Völgarr captures this beautifully! Just getting through the first level/world and beat the boss feels like conquering the world! (The developers of Völgarr have been kind though - back in the days you had often limited lives, limited "Continues", and sometimes no checkpoints at all!)After a while, when you decide to play the game all over again, you suddenly realise how good you've gotten at this game. You're wielding your sword and throwing spears as if you were born doing so. That moment made me smile - it really brings back memories...My thoughts (who am I kidding - you know what I'm gonna say!)I LOVE THIS GAME and anyone who grew up with or has ever happened to fall in love with 16-bit games in particular will too! I began this review feeling quite sophisticated but after writing this and realising how much I really like this game, I end up feeling like a kid on saturday morning - waiting for my best friend to come over for a sleepover with snacks and video games all night!I really have to try to fix my SNES console (showing black sreen of death)...

												Really great game ,each level is totaly different experience.Well done monsters design and matching soundtrack. 												9/10This has got to be the hardest game I've ever played... and I love it. It's so satisfying to learn each world to the point where you get point-perfect movement and the flow needed to reach the boss. You aren't God, ya know? You mess up and you're done for.Game's got a good feel. It teaches you elements of each level at the start of that level. Really good game design. It's really gratifying to destroy the boss of each level, considering how hard it was to get there, keeping the gear you acquired, no less. The game makes maaaaany, subtle references to older games from the 90s, and does so quite well, even.Great music, great art, really immersive.The one lost point is for the level before the end boss. Never a fan of fighting every enemy in the game one last time.I highly recommend this game. It's a great game.

Posted: January 21, 2014
												This game is ridiculously fun. It's claim as a Nintendo Hard game is completely true; not thinking your way through the game will result in death. Not that death requires you to not think it through, you'll just die less from thinking. Knowing and personalizing the controls is the first step in beating this; being able to have every control down will help a lot, since this game requires you to be able to deftly dodge and strike when needed. The bosses can be very puzzle like, since you need to know when to dodge, strike, or otherwise act.Volgarr has two attacks: sword and spear. The sword will probably be used most often, but throwing the spear not only gives you a ranged attack, but can also MAKE A PLATFORM TO STAND AND JUMP FROM. That's incredible! And this isn't just a feature, you are required to use this ability to make it through the game. Alive. There are many secret areas that make you think "I know what to do, but how", as you need to figure out where to throw spears and where to jump onto those spears.Volgarr, being a viking, is a badass. Enemies, being dangerous, can rip Volgarr's armor off to kill him. You don't have a health bar, so much as armor. You start with your shield, a buckler. THEN you upgrade to a better metal shield. THEN you get a helmet! THEN A FLAMING SWORD! Each hit you endure will take a piece of armor off, until you have no shield and thus cannot block attacks. This makes being hit a punishment, not an inconvenience, which I absolutely love.Notes:You can try to avoid enemies altogether to stay alive.You can zoom out, making the graphics better and plan ahead easier.You can set the Zoom out to Toggle which will help a LOT.You can try to learn all the controls, I mean ALL, to look badass and flashy while also retaining armor.Bottom Line is; I love this game and absolutely recommend it's full price. It's hard but very rewarding, in a way that games like Rastan, Dark Souls, older Zelda games, and even Super Mario World portray. If you are easily angered, however, probably don't buy this. You will die a lot before you develop a strategy.

Posted: July 7, 2015
												This game tries to capture the true difficulty of classic arcade platformers. The problem is that the presentation really makes it too frustrating for all but hardcore platformer fans, as there is no real save system (you can reportedly sort of skip already beaten levels, but at a cost), no ability to control the difficulty, a tendency to put you back at the start of a level after you die, and half the levels apparently inaccessible unless you complete every level without really taking damage.Controls are fairly tight and the graphics and music are good, although in the first couple levels I only encountered the same 5 enemy sprites, 3 of which were basically recolors of the same sprite. I also have to give kudos for a Linux port that runs well, including XBox 360 controller support (even rumble works!).Still, this game is intentionally at the Ghosts 'n Goblins level of difficulty, with no concessions to casual players (e.g. old guys with rusty platforming skills who don't have lots of time to play). As a result, I can't recommend it to anyone who is not a huge fan of super-challenging platformers.

Posted: June 17, 2014
												I have a lot of respect for this game. It is certainly one of the most if not the most difficult action platformer I have ever played. Though it is tough to the max, it is equally as fun as it is tough for anyone who enjoys the classic gameplay heavily borrowed from the Rastan Saga and polished up. Not only is this game Rastan without the kinks, but it gives major nods to many classic games of the genre. The "Rise Warrior" at the beginning seems a lot like the "Rise from your grave" when you start a new game on Altered Beast; doesn't it? I've also noticed references to Castlevania, Ghouls n' Ghosts, and Legend of Zelda II: The Adventure of Link. All this has been gleaned as I'm only halfway through the second stage. I'm sure I'll catch more references as I progress, yet many probably continue to slip by right under my nose.If you have a bit of a masochistic streak and a love for all things old school platformer, GAME THIS PLAY!

Posted: October 13, 2013
												This is a breath of fresh air from the modern era of games where the first 2 hours of a game are a tutorial, every enemy has a neon flashing weakpoint, and you're fully capable of hiding everytime you scrape your knee to regain your health. No, none of that♥♥♥♥♥♥with Völgarr the Viking. This is a throwback to the glory days when games didn't hold your hand. Instead Odin hands you a sword, shield, and spear and sends you on you way with a simple "Rise, Warrior. Don't ♥♥♥♥ this up." It's another shining example of how being difficult without resorting to low-blows always results in an extremely rewarding experience. My one word of caution is that you'll have to play the game in a single playthrough like the old days since there's no save system. With that being said, you could easily pause and leave the game running in the background when you need to take a break. As a gauge of what you're in for, it took me 3 hours 26 minutes and 94 deaths to finish my first playthrough and I'd say I'm good at these kind of games.
