Posted: December 29, 2014
												When a store page uses words like "old school hard" or "brutal difficulty", I can see the appeal. Völgarr the Viking is hard in the same way that early entries in the Castlevania series are hard. Yes, it's not something that just anyone can pick up, play, and enjoy. No, this is not necessarily a good thing, but some players need that extra bit of a triumphant feeling in completing a level.   One thing that's clear from the very outset is that this is in no way one of those modern games that so many grognards accuse of excessive handholding. No, you're thrown right into the world from the beginning, with no direction but the innate instinct to go right. Be sure to check out the game's manual, too, as it explains a few helpful concepts that the game's (intentionally) meager tutorial might not make explicitly clear. Be sure to check it out, also, for the fact that it's a loving recreation of the kinds of manuals one finds packaged with (better) retro cartridge games, although black and white would have lent that extra sense of nostalgia.   The graphics are old-school only in the sense that there's a (relatively) limited color palette and movement occurs in only two dimensions, as you slash and spear your way through seemingly endless ranks of palette-swapped enemies of varying strength and ability. There's clearly a lot of love on display in the general and specific "feel" of it all.   Völgarr the Viking is absolutely not for everyone, and it never intends to be, but if you're of the kind who enjoys approaching combat as just as much of a puzzle in rhythm and positioning as the rest of the level, it might just be the game for you.

Posted: April 10, 2016
												Yet another retro work that tries to emulate NES difficulty games. Does it succeed? For the most part, yes.The six worlds are split into two parts with only one checkpoint at the beginning of each part. You have infinite continues, but if you die at any moment in the middle of each part (including boss fights) you'll have to start over from the beginning of that part. Völgarr can slash with his sword, hurl spears at the enemies or on walls to climb them, roll and double jump with the second jump making him do a rolling sword attack a little like in SNES Star Wars games; the only tricky part is the jumping since he can only jump straight up or in diagonals and you cannot change the trajectory once you've jumped, but for the rest it's pretty easy to control.The game is entirely deterministic (except those damn blobs), which means that you can elaborate a safe pattern to reproduce each time you play the level. This definitely helps since the levels are pretty hard and you'll probably need to restart each section many times before you understand how to get past each enemy. It will take you 5 to 8 hours to beat it once depending on your skill.Hardcore players that manage to get to the end of the level almost unharmed will also be rewarded with five alternate paths (basically 5 harder levels with max 3 lives to finish them) and if they finish each one of them you'll get an extra level at the end.Recommended to those who seek for a small, challenging but manageable game.

Posted: November 30, 2013
												Very tricky, but almost never unfair, this game is a real throwback to the games of yesteryear.If you enjoy playing the same level over and over and over, making just a tiny bit of progress with each playthrough, finally reaching the boss after countless retries, only to die over and over before finally beating him, only to start the whole process over in the next world, then this game is for you.Solid, tight gameplay, great graphics and wonderful music (even if the soundtrack is a bit overpriced), this game comes highly recommended for those with the patience and dedication to enjoy it.

Posted: September 16, 2013
												♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, this game is tougher than a pot of boiled ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s!BUT IN A GOOD WAY, HONEST!It truly does live up to the claim of being hard like the games of the past. It's tons of pattern and level memorization, and always remembering what powers are at your disposal.The game is unforgiving, but does not ONCE treat the player like they're stupid. The game KNOWS you're smart and challenges you to prove it through tough enemy, trap, and obstacle placement. There's tons of trail and error, so be prepared to restart a board many a time until you know it like the back of your hand.That said though, the boards can be quite lengthy, which makes the fact that you have to clear them on one life a bit of a chore (given you have to restart from the beginning every death). That's one complaint: no mid-way checkpoints. But I suppose that's something modern games have spoiled us with. So not really a complaint, more like a "UGHHH MODERN GAMING WHHHY" point.Although I do have a legitimate complaint: The controls. I've been playing with a 360 pad which is a no brainer for me given this is a side scrolling platform which, in my books, demands the precision. Now, having said that, I find the controls while responsive and good, can also be pretty clunky. Does that make sense? No? Well lemme try and explain.You basically work on 3 inputs, A, X and your joystick (d-pad). A jumps, X attacks, and your joystick moves. Simple right? Well, holding up on the joystick draws your spear, and then pressing X throws said spear (and with later power ups, holding up for an extended period powers your throw). I'm not sure if it affects play or not, but sometimes while jumping, I'll hold up and draw my spear, which often gets me killed. I'm not sure if it adjusts the player's hit box while doing so, but I'm going to say it does for the sake of my argument, although it may turn out I'm just crap.Second point: You have 2 jumps. A standard leap, and pressing jump once again while in a jump will cause you to spin your sword and perform a double jump. Pretty standard fare, right?Well, if you just plain press jump, you'll jump straight up and be unable to move, but if you move and jump, you're committed to your jump arch (think original Castlevania style). So, ok, not so bad right?This is where things get UUGHGHHHH.If you are in mid jump arch and double jump without holding the intended direction you want to go in, your second jump CANCELS your jump arch.Now I know WHY they did it, for more precise platforming, but it can really mess you up if you don't anticipate the game. And one slip up means you can be toast and have to start all over again. It's a bit frustrating.GOOD POINTS THOUGH!The simplistic controls take getting used to, but they can be mastered easily since there isn't a whole lot of complexity to them (besides what I listed above). And while restarting a level is a pain, the pixel art is soooo gorgeous and the animations are so smooth and nice that it eases that pain a bit.As well, the game does a great job of building avatar strength through the power up system, and the best example of this is through the spears.Just plain Jane, you can throw a basic spear and more often than not, it'll kill an enemy in one hit and destroy itself. A second upgrade will give you a shield that can block up to two hits. Now this third upgrade gives you a slightly cooler looking shield AND powers up your spear. How does this affect your spear? Well now you can ♥♥♥♥ING PIN GUYS TO WALLS! It's so bad♥♥♥♥♥ let me tell you. If you can nail a line of enemies with a fully charged spear, nothing screams satisfaction like watching them all get sent flying by your man-missile. Upgrades beyond this add additional hit points to the player, and eventually a fire spraying sword.In short, if you're looking for a classic feeling game with a steep (but rewarding) challenge, pick it up!If you're looking for something a bit more relaxed, you may want to look else where.I give Volgarr an 8 out of 10!

Posted: January 4, 2015
Volgarr the Viking is a platformer, beat-em-up game. It's the kind of game that brings back memories from the 8, 16, maybe even 32-bit era. It has many similarities to good old games such as Ninja Gaiden or Ghosts n' Goblins. Let me tell you one thing, if you like a challenge, this game is the game for you!Overall: I'd give it a 7.3/10. Its good, but I'm kind of put off by this game by multiple factors.Controls & Handling: 8/10. I used the Xbox 360 Controller for the game, and it was kind of awkward at first, using the joystick as movement. I prefer using the D-Pad and luckily, they added the option to! Some other controls are kind of weird like your double jumps acts as an attack move, so I keep on pushing my attack button in the air instead of my jump button, but that's my fault. Some tights spots that are downward are kind of iffy, but the Right Trigger also acts as a "Pogo Attack", so I'll leave it at that.Graphics: 6/10. The graphics are supposed to be two dimensional and blocky, reminiscent of the older times, but blood... blood everywhere. Sometimes unnecessarily large amounts of blood. In all honesty, it kind of puts me off.Storyline: To be honest, I couldn't get far enough to see if there was any storyline. It just made me so mad! It's really  challenging.Music: 8/10. It really fits the game, and it's viking theme. I don't know how to describe it... like... Nordic? Viking?

Posted: January 5, 2015
												This game is a solid platformer and a heck of a good time. The whole game has very little random chance and when you do well it's because you improved your skill. Also the only way to learn is to die, if you don't like games that use that as a teaching tool then stay away.

												Imagine Dark Souls as a retro-styled platformer. New players will have a hell of a time adjusting to the game's difficulty curve.  DISCLAIMER: This is a first impressions review, and NOT a full review, if you want a full review, then please read better reviews then mine Volgarr the Viking is a game developed by Crazy Viking Studios and published by Adult Swim Games. This game is very challengingI will only recommend this game, if you want a very challenging but a good well designed game. If you are looking for a game that you can simply breeze through, stay far, far away from this gameThis game is very responsive and accurate with its controls however it is strongly recommended to play with a controllerOverall, this is a well-designed, albeit very challenging, action platformer. It has stiff jumping mechanics, challenging level design, two-hit deaths, and a medieval/fantasy setting in the format of an action platformerI would only recommend it to people who really want a challenge, otherwise, steer clear away from Volgarr the Viking RECOMMENDED :)  Also, best to play with a controller

Posted: February 13, 2016
												This game is clearly a modern updated take on Rastan. That was a game I liked as a kid but never got much into because the game never seemed worth suffering its own difficulty. This game falls into the same category for me. It's got so much good stuff, but the start-over-from-way-back-when-you-die mechanic really died out for me with the Super Nintendo. The notion that fun is replaying a large section over and over again where one hit equates to failure isn't my cup of tea anymore. It also features that other classic mechanic: knock-back-on-hit (if you're lucky, not straight into a pit). So despite the moderately udpated retro graphics, a decent soundtrack, and controls that feature some depth, the game fails to be something I'd recommend in general. If you're looking for an old school feel in a modern package, this may be one of the best offerings in that regards. But for someone who has played hundreds of those games, and is no longer looking for that kind of time wasting or frustration potential, I have to pass. 6/10

												If remembering the term 'Arcade difficulty' brings fond feelings, and you love 16-bit style action platformers, then this is definitely the game for you. Posted: December 27, 2013
												Oh man... Did you game in the 80s? Classic NES such as Ninja Gaiden and Wizards & Warriors? Do you love a game that is unapologetically tough (but not unfair)? Do you remember sinking quarters into Stryder? If the answer is yes, this game is totally for you. No save points, just check points. You die, you start the level over. Get to the boss and die? You start the level over. Quit the game? Start the game from the start. Never unfair or cheap, this game pushes you (much in the same way as Dark Souls but this isn't near the sadist/masochist relationship of that).I can't recommend this game enough for us in our late 20s to late 30s. This is the stuff we grew up on. A fantastic homage. If you like metal, it's like the Skeletonwitch/Havok/Municpal Waste of video games.MAYBE some of the youngins will join the club of tough games for toughness sake. And maybe we'll let them in. ;)

Posted: August 22, 2015
												A tough-but-fair platformer with heavy 16/32-bit influences. The levels are full of hazzards and enemies that will destroy you if you aren't careful, so this is not a game to blaze through; instead, you must take your time and plan your actions. You will die a lot, but there is no life system (unless you attempt the hard endings) so you can take what you've learned and get right back into it. I greatly enjoyed the gameplay, and the music is fantastic.Piece of advice: open the options menu, go into settings, and activate the "look ahead as toggle" option. This allows you to zoom out the screen and keep it that way until you press the zoom button again (space by default). This lets you see further ahead and have more warning from enemies.

Posted: April 25
												Solid, heavy, and brutal.The controls support the notion that you are a heavy, strong viking. The game is quite difficult and requires mastering the controls in order to succeed. Solid plaforming and combat come together to make this a challenging adventure.Controls are stiff, but rather than taking away from the player's experience it adds more of a "heavy" and "strong" feeling behind actions, fitting in with the theme of the character and setting. Enemies and levels are designed around these controls so deaths, while frequent and frustrating, are "fair" and lend themselves to helping the player become better through experience.Enemy movements are subtly varied but tailored around the player's controls, forcing the player to adapt tactics while perfecting his handle on the controls.I recommend this to fans of hard-core platformers.

Posted: April 26
												Rise, Warrior! ROAR!Volgarr the Viking is an awesome game. It has great graphics, excellent gameplay and a great soundtrack. There will be minor spoilers for the story:You play Volgarr, a viking with a mighty sword and an unlimited supply of spears that he can use to attack enemies or use as platforms. Your task is to travel through five worlds (each consisting of two sections) and defeat the bosses to open Fafnir's tower. Should you be good enough, you can obtain warrior spirits that serve as lives to play the more difficult parts of worlds 2-6. Depending on what you do, you can earn one out of three endings.Mark my words though: This game is not for everybody. It has a high difficulty spike. Playing Volgarr for the first time can be extremely frustrating. I spent 3 hours of my first playthrough in the first two worlds before I got good enough alone. However the more I learned how to control Volgarr and the neat tricks he can do, the easier it got. Now I got all achievements and just completed the game a second time on the Valkyrie path.I would say that Volgarr is basically Dark Souls the Jump n' Run. Once you have learned the game's tricks, it becomes extremely enjoyable and rewarding. Try to answer these questions:Do you like to get challenged by a game?Do you like to try, try, try again until you finally beat a world?Do you like to eventually master a hard game and feel like a beast when you played through it a second, third or even fourth and so forth time?If you can answer all these questions with yes, then you should check out Volgarr. If you don't like to get constantly killed until you finally mastered a difficult section, then better turn around now and look for something else to play.
